Reviews:
Good old, classic Virtual Villagers. Nostalgia attack. | This is the best game I've played in my life. Red dead? NO. FNAF? NO. God of War? NO. Elden Ring? NO. None of these FAKE LOSER GARBAGE GAMES can even hold a CANDLE to the shining star that is Virtual Villagers: A New Hope. For starters, the visuals are perfect. They leave just enough to the interpretation of the viewer while still evoking a nostalgic feeling deep within your soul. The audio is delightful. I often say "hey" in the cadence of my villagers in day-to-day life. The lore runs so deep, Dark Souls has NOTHIN on this. I cannot recommend this game enough. It is truly the most perfect idle game EVER. Also, there is no language filter on your villagers names so you can have a bald 9-year-old named "COSTCO" or "WALMART" and no one bats an eye. Truly ethereal. | Great puzzles to tease your brain along with time and character management. I've played this before it was on Steam, great game overall. | I love this game! I grew up playing Virtual Villagers 3, so this is very nostalgic for me. 
I love the puzzles, the building and survival aspects of this game!

This game has one good thing going for it: the puzzles are truly excellent. Not too hard, no too easy, some really satisfying. But the rest of the game is all over the place. Voice acting is hit and miss, locations are usually really good, but the story is pretty nonsensical in a lot of respects. It starts off like a simple, detective-esque game, then it becomes very dark very fast (with things like [spoiler] on-screen cannibalism, burning someone alive and watching it decompose in front of you, seeing several dismembered dead bodies, and the aftermath of torture [/spoiler]; it definitely crossed more than a few lines for me), and yet it ends in an almost childish way, with an awful first cutscene for the final confrontation, and a desperate attempt at a cliffhanger for a sequel in a shorter, second cutscene). It also has a very weird mixture of christian lore and lovecraftian lore, which doesn't really make any sense (Lovecraft is all about cosmic horror, the feeling of dread and despair from being insignificant in a vast cosmos with beings far superior and knowledge that our mind couldn't even process; including a somewhat benevolent god who is "the god", and including other "gods" that are actually just "demons", even when being referenced as "gods", is nonsensical to say the least).
It definitely left me feeling disappointed more than a few times, and it overstayed its welcome for a few hours at the very least. I can't really recommend it. | I played it a long time ago. I really like it, that's why I bought it. 
Great game.

Plants vs. Zombies brings to mind the brilliant designers of the classic arcade games of the early 80's. Designers who, with access to scarily primitive hardware, scant complex controls, and often the singular player-controlled verb of "move," created iconic, immortal and wonderfully fun video games. Plants vs. Zombies is a game played with the mouse, and there are no exceptions made to this premise. There are no hotkeys, or alternate control schemes. It is a game your grandma could play, and I bet she'd like it. Also just like those old arcade games, Plants vs. Zombies, in its genius birthed of simplicity, comes to mind rapidly when considering what games are prime examples of art. Rest in Peace PopCap. | [h1]El juego de las plantas[/h1]

Game Name: The Secret of Monkey Island: Special Edition
Reviews:
This is barely a positive recommendation.

The original game was great, and it's great that you can switch freely between them, because the remaster has issues. The interface of the original game felt dated when it came out, but worked okay. The remaster tries to update the interface, but with limited success - and in many cases the compromise between what a modern audience expects from an interface and the archaic old interface is downright worse than the old interface. It is often needlessly frustrating to play this game - the fight is with the interface to solve a puzzle you know conceptually how to do, and this is a terrible thing for any game, but especially a point and click adventure game.

It doesn't help that having played the game as a kid, and imagined what the pixelated graphics would look like - the update graphics often don't match my imagination of what the characters should look like.

But - the music is all spot on - as I remember the music rather than how the music actually was - and the voice acting is great. I've only found one or two characters so far that don't sound how I think they should sound.

What I want is to play the old game with the new music and the voice acting - but this will do. | I play this game once every 10 years or so on my best-of rotation. It definitely shows its age with the graphics and animation but mechanically it's very responsive and enjoyable. The story is great, the humor is classic, the music is peak nostalgia for me, and it's fun. | The Secret of Monkey Island is Adventure games at their finest. It's a all-time classic title for a reason. The writing is hilarious, the art and music are charming, and the puzzles are engaging. There isn't much to be said about the original title that hasn't been said already. However, this is the Special Edition, and I intend to review it as its own title.

The TSoM:SE is a very faithful rendition of the original. However, it clearly was designed as a console port more so than anything else. The control scheme is very controller-centric, which can take away from the experience for PC players. Of course, you can always hot-swap to the classic version, but then you miss out on the wonderful voice acting. If only there were a PC-centric control set as well, or even the option to have voice acting on the classic edition. | Remake de un tÃ­tulo muy especial para mi, ya que se trata de mi primer videojuego de PC.
GrÃ¡ficos y sonidos actualizados, dejando atrÃ¡s los pÃ­xeles como puÃ±os y sutituyÃ©ndolos por grÃ¡ficos dibujados a mano, pudiendo tambiÃ©n escuchar por fin las voces de los protagonistas
Pese a tratarse de un excelente juego, guardando la esencia del original tanto en sus puzles como en su humor, reconozco que las mecÃ¡nicas se han quedado un tanto obsoletas.
TambiÃ©n comentar que ese juego que tantas buenas horas disfrutÃ© en mi juventud, apenas me ha durado 3 horas y media

Je n'ai aucune idÃ©e de comment ce jeu mÃ©diocre est arrivÃ© dans ma bibliothÃ¨que. (devait Ãªtre packagÃ© avec un album de U2)

Ich spiele das Spiel nun nach bestimmt 15 Jahren oder so zum zweiten Mal und wollte ein wenig in Erinnerungen schwelgen, und mich vergewissern, ob das Spiel auch wirklich so gut ist, wie ich es in Erinnerung habe. Und ja, ist es!

Klar, die Grafik ist heute nur noch mittel schÃ¶n anzusehen, aber das hatte ich auch nach so viel Zeit nicht anders erwartet. 

Das Spiel kann (und sollte) auf jeden Fall in der deutschen Sprachversion gespielt werden (es ist ja auch im Original auf deutsch vertont worden). Es hat sowohl eine spannende, ernste Story (die am Ende vielleicht ein bisschen klischeehaft wird, aber das ist verzeihlich, denke ich), ist sich aber auch nie zu schade fÃ¼r einen Witz, oder eine Anspielung auf (deutsche) Popkultur. Die Sprecherinnen und Sprecher machen eine wirklich gute Arbeit (wobei man bei Nina manchmal das GefÃ¼hlt hat, sie ist doch etwas sehr locker und gelassen, bei allem was ihr so widerfÃ¤hrt :D). 

Ein paar LogiklÃ¼cken hat man natÃ¼rlich wie immer, vor allem dabei warum jeder auf der Welt, vom vereinsamten Indigenen im Wald, bis zum PfÃ¶rtner am anderen Ende der Welt akzentfrei und perfekt deutsch spricht (oder soll man stattdessen annehmen, dass das jeweils nur fÃ¼r die Spieler Ã¼bersetzt ist und Nina und Max dafÃ¼r sÃ¤mtliche Sprachen der Weltgeschichte perfekt beherrschen?). Aber naja, alles nur meckern auf hohem Niveau. 

Das Spiel macht SpaÃŸ und hat keine vÃ¶llig absurden RÃ¤tsel. Es gibt eine integrierte RÃ¤tselhilfe fÃ¼r die Minigames und eine Hotspotanzeige, also alles was man braucht. Vielleicht wird man ein paar Mal einen Guide fÃ¼r die Details prÃ¼fen mÃ¼ssen, aber im Prinzip kommt man recht gut mit Logik und Rumprobieren durch. 

Ich kann mich an keine nervigen Sequenzen erinnern, oder irgendwas das mich grob gestÃ¶rt hÃ¤tte.

Tipp: Auf jeden Fall die (Post)credits Scenes nicht verpassen. | I don't know what to think of this game, it starts off with really easy puzzles, but at some point the solutions become nonsensical. Last 1/3 of the game i was in a cycle of spending an hour to find a solution, then solving one puzzle, then wandering around again for another hour. All in all I manged to solve the game in 16 hours.

I was going to say this game holds up really well being from the turn of the millennium, but was surprised this game was released in 2006. Graphics and menus seem a bit dated for its time.

I guess since the game was good enough that I was motivated to finish it, I will give it a thumbs up. Not nearly as good as the Syberia series, but probably if you are a hardcore PnC fan and looking for something to play, get this at discount. | The story is very interesting, well-made and well-presented.

The puzzles tho.. really 50/50. Many of them make no sense imo and there were atleast 20 places were I would not have been able to progress on my own and only made it because I read a walkthrough.

That is also the reason that I will not play the 2nd game or any other of the 'Secret Files' - games.

 | The game also comes with a DLC, which includes the following items:

1. A Toxic Community: Mistakes are rarely forgiven. Unless youâ€™re playing with friends, be prepared to face harsh criticism, often from younger players. The gameâ€™s multiplayer is largely populated by school-aged players who donâ€™t hold back.


2. Disruptive Adults: Itâ€™s not just the kids causing chaosâ€”some adults blast music through their microphones, assuming everyone else shares their taste. Spoiler: they donâ€™t.


3. Frequent AFKs: Teamwork can fall apart when a teammate goes inactive, whether theyâ€™re brewing tea, taking a smoke break, or simply wandering off mid-game. And yes, it often happens right after youâ€™ve generously used your first aid kit on them.


4. Team Abandonment: Lone wolves running off to the far corners of the map, only to be overwhelmed by infected, are a common sight. Theyâ€™re quick to flood the chat with colorful language before rage-quitting the game.


5. Difficulty Disputes: Some players join games on "Expert" difficulty only to demand a downgrade. If their request is denied, they might sabotage the team before leaving the server entirely.


6. Vote Kicks: Occasionally, youâ€™ll encounter players who inexplicably start a vote to kick you from the game. When you ask why? Crickets.



The Verdict: Despite the chaotic community, Left 4 Dead 2 remains a phenomenal experience. The graphics are a significant step up from the first game, the mechanics feel more polished, and thereâ€™s a greater variety of weapons and infected to enjoy. However, surviving the online experience without a calming remedy might be just as challenging as surviving the zombie apocalypse itself. | [h1]å†™äº†800å­—çš„æ¨èæ–‡ï¼Œæ‰‹æ¬ ç‚¹äº†ä¸€ä¸‹"å¦"å…¨æ²¡äº†ã€‚ä¸è¯´äº†è¡€å‹é«˜äº†,å¤´æ™•ã€‚[/h1]æ€»ä¹‹å°±æ˜¯ã€Šå…³äºä¸€ä¸ªèŒæ–°GMODç©ä¹…äº†æ— èŠç›´æ¥å»ç©L4D1å¤šäººå› å¤ªèœåå¤è¢«åƒµå°¸è™è€Œè¢«é˜Ÿå‹æŠ›å¼ƒä¼¤å¿ƒè‡ªè´£å¸è½½æ¸¸æˆè¿‡åŠå¹´å¥½å¥‡è¿›L4D2çŸ¥é“ç©å•äººç†Ÿæ‚‰å®˜å›¾åŠç©æ³•è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å‘ç°äº†èƒ½æ‰“MODç»“æœä¸€å‘ä¸å¯æ”¶æ‹¾åœ°æœå„ç§è¿›é˜¶æ”»ç•¥æ•™ç¨‹æå‡è‡ªå·±æ¸¸æˆä½“éªŒå’Œèƒ½åŠ›åŠªåŠ›ä¸å‘é˜Ÿå‹å¯ä»ç„¶å¾ˆèœä½†æ˜¯å¾ˆæ„Ÿè°¢å¸¦èŒæ–°å…¥å‘çš„æœ‹å‹ä»¬ä»¥åŠåˆ›æ„å·¥åŠçš„å¤§ä½¬ä»¬ç»™è¿™æ¸¸æˆç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡ç”Ÿå‘½çš„äº‹ã€‹ | ĞšÑ€ÑƒÑ‚Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹ Ñ Ğ´Ñ€ÑƒĞ·ÑŒÑĞ¼Ğ¸ (ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹Ğµ Ğ² ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°ÑÑ‚)! Ğ•ÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ñ€ĞµĞ´ĞºĞ¸Ğµ Ğ´Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ¶ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ñ, ĞºÑƒÑ‡Ğ° Ğ¿ÑƒÑˆĞµĞº Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¿Ğ° Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ¼Ğ±Ğ¸, ĞºĞ¾Ñ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ°Ñ Ğ±ÑƒĞ´ĞµÑ‚ Ğ¼ĞµĞ´Ğ»ĞµĞ½Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğ°ÑÑ‚ÑƒĞ¿Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ğ½Ğ° Ğ¿ÑÑ‚ĞºĞ¸ Ğ¸ Ğ¸Ñ… ÑÑŠĞµĞ´Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ. Ğ’ Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ‰ĞµĞ¼, Ğ²ĞµÑĞµĞ»Ğ¾, Ñ€ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ. | Left 4 Dead 2 (L4D2), released by Valve in 2009, is the gold standard for cooperative zombie shooters. Featuring intense survival gameplay, smart AI, and an incredible atmosphere, L4D2 delivers an unmatched multiplayer experience. With its fast-paced action, diverse weapons, and unpredictable enemy encounters, this game remains one of the most thrilling and replayable co-op shooters ever made.

Gameplay â€“ Pure, Adrenaline-Fueled Action
L4D2 is all about co-op survival. You and three teammates must fight through hordes of the undead, navigating through various maps and completing objectives to reach safety. The key to survival? Teamwork, strategy, and adaptability.

The gunplay is tight and satisfying, with a wide selection of weapons including assault rifles, shotguns, SMGs, sniper rifles, and melee weapons like axes, katanas, and even frying pans! Every encounter feels dynamic, thanks to the AI Director, which adjusts the difficulty based on your teamâ€™s performance, ensuring no two playthroughs are ever the same.

Special Infected â€“ Enemies That Keep You on Edge
Beyond the standard zombie horde, L4D2 introduces Special Infected that force players to work together:

Tank â€“ A massive brute that can throw debris and crush survivors.
Witch â€“ A terrifying enemy that, if startled, can instantly incapacitate a survivor.
Smoker â€“ Uses a long tongue to drag players away from their team.
Hunter â€“ A fast, agile infected that pounces on survivors and pins them down.
Boomer â€“ Explodes in a shower of bile, attracting a massive horde.
Charger â€“ Charges through groups, slamming a survivor into the ground.
Spitter â€“ Creates pools of acid that deal heavy damage.
Each Special Infected forces different team strategies, making communication and positioning absolutely crucial.

Campaigns & Maps â€“ A Horror Movie Experience
L4D2 features multiple campaigns, each set in diverse, apocalyptic locations across the southern U.S.:

Dead Center â€“ A chaotic mall escape reminiscent of classic zombie films.
The Parish â€“ A tense race across New Orleans to reach an evacuation zone.
Swamp Fever â€“ A creepy, foggy swamp filled with infected dangers.
Hard Rain â€“ A unique campaign featuring a devastating hurricane that changes the environment.
Dark Carnival â€“ A fan-favorite, featuring a deadly amusement park with a thrilling rollercoaster finale.
Each campaign feels like a mini zombie movie, packed with cinematic set pieces, interactive environments, and intense finales.

Multiplayer & Game Modes â€“ Endless Replayability
L4D2 offers several game modes that keep the action fresh:

Campaign Mode â€“ Classic co-op survival through story-driven levels.
Versus Mode â€“ One team plays as survivors, while the other controls the Special Infected.
Survival Mode â€“ See how long you can last against endless waves of zombies.
Scavenge Mode â€“ A competitive mode where teams race to collect fuel cans while being hunted.
Mutation Mode â€“ Weekly game modifiers that add fun twists to gameplay.
Thanks to modding support and the Steam Workshop, the community has also created hundreds of custom maps, weapons, and campaigns, making L4D2â€™s replayability practically infinite.

Graphics & Sound â€“ Immersive and Timeless
Even years after release, L4D2â€™s atmospheric lighting, detailed environments, and gruesome effects hold up well. Zombies react realistically to gunfire, and the sound design is masterful, with eerie background noises, terrifying growls from Special Infected, and intense musical cues that heighten the suspense.

The voice acting and character interactions bring the survivors to life, making them memorable and adding humor to the chaos.

Why Left 4 Dead 2 is a Must-Play
L4D2 is the perfect blend of action, horror, and co-op gameplay. Whether youâ€™re playing with friends or AI teammates, the intense combat, unpredictable enemy encounters, and endless replayability make every match a thrilling adventure.

ğŸ”¹ Final Rating: 10/10
Left 4 Dead 2 is a masterpiece of cooperative gaming. If you love zombies, action, and teamwork, this is an absolute must-play that still delivers endless fun and excitement after more than a decade.

Game Name: Broken Sword 2 - the Smoking Mirror: Remastered (2010)
Reviews:
I didn't play the original of this game, I missed it when it was free. 
I love P&N games especially older ones, but this one I could've gone without playing.

Maybe it's because this version of the game suffers from being a remaster, I wanted to like it but I just don't. Game originally came out in 1997 and they remastered it in 2010. Sometimes the original needs to be left alone.

I played Broken Sword 5 a few years ago as it was gifted to me and I really liked that game, so after that I decided to try to play more in the series.
Unfortunately this game was the second game in the series I tried and I didn't like it. 

I can see why people like this game, but it honestly wasn't for me.

I only finished the game for the achievements.

I had audio issues throughout the game, sometimes the voices were lower, and some of the cut scene videos wound up being really loud. I noticed that the speech would be in one ear, and in another instant it would be in the other.

While playing this game, I just wanted to push through it to get it over with, I played with a walk through to try to just go through the game as fast as possible. 

I decided to check out a bit of game play from the original version and I don't get why they made some of the changes they did. I preferred the way they did the speech (words above their heads) in the original over the way they did the remaster with the HD portraits. The inventory system was done much better too not sure why they changed that.

The game isn't bad, I just didn't enjoy it, I didn't care for the story either. | Saison 2 trÃ¨s captivante ! Bravo Georgie ;) | Pietra miliare del Punto e Clicca.
Parliamo davvero di un gioco, che ha fatto la storia. 
Il doppiaggio, la StoryBoard, le dinamiche, sono davvero incredibili..
Io lo definisco, un Comfort Game. 
Ci gioco e rigioco per piacere e per pura compagnia... <3 | These games are lots of fun! | un gioco che ho ritrovato ! spettacolare sempre

-Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½. ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ°Ñ ĞºĞ²ĞµÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ°Ñ ÑĞµÑ€Ğ¸Ñ ÑĞºĞ°Ñ‚Ğ¸Ğ»Ğ°ÑÑŒ Ğ² Ğ¼Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ½Ñ‹Ğ¹ Ğ½Ğ° Ñ‚Ğ¾ Ğ²Ñ€ĞµĞ¼Ñ 3Ğ´. Ğ¾ÑˆĞ¸Ğ±ĞºĞ°.
~ÑÑĞ¶ĞµÑ‚. Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¶ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğµ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑĞºĞ¾Ğ³Ğ¾ Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ĞµĞºÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ²Ğ°.
-Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ„Ğ¸ĞºĞ°. Ğ·Ñ€Ñ-Ğ·Ñ€Ñ. | First of all, the port is broken. When you start the game it will do that classic old-game thing where it changes your screen resolution, completely messing up your open windows (not the OS).

When you make any settings changes in the game, they don't save for the next time you run the game. 

Instead, what you have to do is go into the Steam folder, go to the game .exe and enter the properties. Navigate over to compatibility, tick the "Run this program in compatibility mode" and select "Windows XP (Service Pack 3)". Then you have to go to Steam and enter the game's properties in Steam; in â€œGeneralâ€ you go to Launch Options and type this in "-w [1920] -h [1080]" (or whatever your screen resolution is)

FINALLY, the game will launch in the correct resolution, and won't bork up your monitor(s). (You have to do that compatibility mode or else the steam property change won't do anything)

Now that we're finally done with this tedious process JUST to be able to comfortably play the game... you'll have to fix the audio and turn on the subtitles each time you launch the game, but at least this isn't as annoying as fixing your desktop every time you launch the game. If you have a PS1, just run an emulator. Skip the Steam version if you can.

Now, besides thatâ€”I really liked the writing. So far, this is my favourite Broken Sword game. Maybe the issue is that I wasn't familiar with the characters in the first game, so I wasn't as invested in what was happening. Therefore like in sequel movies, you already know all the characters, so you only need to enjoy the story instead. The second game... honestly, I don't remember it, it's like a fever dream to me: I remember having played it, and I wrote a review for it... but what happened? Did I enjoy it? Since it didn't leave an impression on me, I assume it wasn't good. 

But THIS! This game, I loved!

Now let me clear some things up. Part of why I loved it is because it has the charm of... objectively being bad. For example, the voice acting isn't that good... Like any time a character needs to exude some actual emotions besides simply chatting, this gives Trolls 2 vibes of "They're eating her. Then they're gonna eat me. Oh my gooooooood" And I love them for it! It's so soulful!

The controls are a bit... difficult. They're camera-dependent unless the character moves from one screen to another. So if you press â€œSâ€ to move towards the camera, and then the character moves to a new scene where they appear on the right side of the screen, as long as you're still holding â€œSâ€ the character will keep walking in the same continuous line: but from your perspective, they're now walking to the left instead of down. If you release â€œSâ€ and then press it again, the character will start walking down again, instead of the "original direction" if that makes sense? 

Anyway, I'm telling you about the controls because it's important you know about 1 section in this game where the controls WILL mess you up in a time-sensitive section. To make a metaphor to avoid spoilers: Imagine you're playing Indiana Jones: Raiders of the Lost Ark. You're in the opening scene where you have to run from the rolling boulder. You press "S" thinking "I want Indy to run towards the camera, so I have to press downwards" But no, Indy runs "backwards" towards the boulder. Releasing â€œSâ€ and pressing it again will make him run towards the cameraâ€”the desired directionâ€” but because you moved towards the boulder for a mili-second, itâ€™s enough to make you unable to escape it. I've tested: pressing "W", thinking "Indy is already facing the camera, so maybe pressing the forward key will make him walk towards the camera" but nope, he walks towards the boulder AS WELL! What you HAVE to do, is tap "A", making Indy turn left, THEN "S" to make him run towards the camera. That's how you "solve" this unintentional puzzle.

Speaking of Puzzles, the hint system is gone, including the 4th game (I don't have a favourable review for that bad boy). So unless you enjoyed solving the Goat puzzle without using Hints in the first game (I spent 3 hours before giving in and checking a Hint) you'll want to have an actual walkthrough guide open just to figure out what the puzzle even is. You'll see a bunch of crates standing about... but... why am I supposed to move them... like what is the destination? There are crates here that I can move, sure... but why do I WANT to move them? Capisce?

Like there was a climbable ledge that I didn't know could be climbed, so I didn't know what the puzzle wanted of me.

Closing remarks: 

Even though I have ALL these complaints: I really enjoyed the game. Despite this game making me mad at times: I loved this game! It's beautiful WITH its flaws!

Also Nico is tastefully hot in this game. | Ja is ganz nett. Kommt Ã¼berhaupt nicht an die ersten zwei Teile ran. In keinster Weise. Aber viele Dialoge sind lustig. Ich empfehle es mal, weils so alt is. Ich hab mich gut unterhalten gefÃ¼hlt, obwohl das Spiel ganz schÃ¶n plump is. Is halt nen Kistenschiebesimulator.

One of those puzzle games, cute and cuddly on the outside, but with hardcore brain-metling levels by the end of the game.
The difficulty curve is quite smooth and balanced - levels in the middle are very pleasant to go through.

If I have to pick a problem with Toki Tori is that sometimes solution may include good exectution, and not just logic - but these cases are few and far between. And time-rewind mechanic makes is as un-annoying as possible.

Game Name: SEGA Mega Drive and Genesis Classics
Reviews:
Good emulator, terrible decision to delist it to bump up sonic sales | Of course they delisted it! That's what SEGA does. They make a compilation but only one press of it, then they make a new version for the next consoles but it's worse. Then they put the games on Steam and remove them because they're working on ANOTHER compilation, this time with an atrocious UI, and later remove that as well. Mark my words, Switch 2 is coming out for way more money than reasonable and SEGA mentioned wanting to revive some of their popular franchises, two of which have since been made better by other companies, two of which were tried previously and came out awful - they're not making AAA revisits of the greats, they're making WayForward vibe games for $40 each and will pump out another compilation. I want to be wrong and say they're gonna give us gold but it's SEGA. Trust me, I want this to age very poorly but, c'mon, we care about them more than they do about themselves. | For its time, I found it a fair exchange to legally purchase ROMs without any BS. Unfortunately there's not as much money in that compared to repackaging them or putting them behind a subscription service.

I respect the original concept but not the decision of delisting it to avoid competing with yourself. A similar sentiment towards the also delisted Dreamcast Collection. | Realmente queria jugar varios juegos de sega genesis en esta coleccion. Compre este juego en un pack hace mucho, pero lamentablemente, no lo instale cuando lo compre. Y ahora a la fecha del 2025, resulta que ni aunque tenga el juego en mi libreria, me sirve poder acceder a la biblioteca completa de los juegos de Genesis. 
Al menos en la Switch pude comprar la coleccion y esos juegos se mantendran. Pero en mi Steam Deck, la biblioteca que aparece en la interfaz del juego es desalentadora, solo 2 juegos DLC aparecen. Una perdida de tiempo total. | I bought this â€œcollection â€œ before it was pulled from the store. Once I DL it and opened it there was only one game in the collection. Golden Axe. Am I missing something? I thought it had more than 50 games in this like the others.

La breve sottotrama che riguarda il passato di nico, per quanto interessante, si interrompe prima della metÃ  del gioco, non venendo piu ripresa. Gli enigmi aggiuntivi sono carini.

In conclusione, dovendo scegliere, vi consiglio o la versione originale oppure l'ultima versione rimasterizzata, che in teoria non ha toccato alcun contenuto del gioco ma solo la veste grafica.

 | Medium-Easy difficult story with puzzles. Nice old adventure game. I love it when I played it twenty years ago.

This is has to be the worst designed point and click i ever played to this day. Story is your standard B-movie like mystical thriller, nothing special in that regard. VA are atrocious, listening to americans pretending to be french physically hurts. Narrative presentation is... also atrocious. Developers tried to create non linear game and failed hard. Often dialogs make no sense, as character start to blabber about things that did not happened at that moment or protagonist had no clue at that point of time. One of the characters works just like exposition machine. She exists simply to provide exposition dumps to protagonist, dumps that often should not even concerns him at that moment. Existence of such a character in the storyline is the best example of writers impotence.

Than we have puzzles... yeah... and its the worst part of the game, not because of moon logic or something like that, no. Because most of puzzles here are solved by tedious selection method. But thats not all this game from 2002 has... drum roll... A SOFT LOCK! Yep! You thought that by that time developers all over the globe realized that soft locks are bad, but apparently not blokes that created this steaming piece of something.

To the trashbin it goes! Thumb down.

PS: considering potential for soft lock, you may want to restart game... and there will wait an another surprise - unskipable dialogs! Because devs really, really wanted you to listen to their atrocious VA reading their atrocious nonsensical lines written in service of a story about evil wizard.

Legitimately a fun and unique setting for a game. The single player is also fun and interesting, a shame this game is so unknown, just like bloody good time. | Hard to recommend now but the game is fun and I had a lot of fun times with The Ship playing with friends. It just feels like a corpse of what it once was and makes me crave for those days of coming home from school and playing games with friends <3. Buggy as all h3ll though :( | jogo bom pra passar o tempo. e divertido tambem!

These games could use an additional bump anyway (and them bloody numbers). Since I'm here, gotta say the first game isn't entirely representative, they only get bigger and better. I adore the series it's one of my favorites and I recommend the series to any of my P&C friends when they ask for recommendations. I highly recommend trying to play the whole series, even if you have to wait for a sale because it can be worth it if the story is your style.
I got hooked on the games, when I would finish one I would go buy more because I got caught in this story and I followed through to the end with no regrets. 
The first doesn't really do the whole series justice, but honestly the more I went on the better the story got all the way to the end.

My first playthrough was about 2h 20m, my second playthrough was about 1h 40m.
This is a very short game, it's very simplistic, and it's easy to beat under 2 hours.

This game is an easy entry into the series but it does have it flaws, it's more of a "paper and pencil" detective style and not a "put a bunch of objects together" kind of game. 

The game hardcore (like most) relies on you to exhaust dialogue options and some of them are easy to miss but are necessary to do a specific puzzle. -[spoiler]Mainly the talking to Joey about his powers before you try to deal with Kelly to grab what you need from the room.[/spoiler]
Rosa and Joey actually make a good team, especially the more through the series you go, I love them.

I know this won't be for everyone, but I say try to give it a shot, it migh just be worth it. | Really enjoyed this game and gobbled up the whole series shortly after playing this. Love the storyline and characters. | This oneâ€™s a solid follow-up to [i]The Blackwell Legacy[/i], offering another engaging, atmospheric entry in the series. I really appreciated the way it deepens the lore of the Blackwell universe while maintaining the same moody, ghostly charm that made the first game so compelling. Playing as Lauren Blackwell, a no-nonsense, chain-smoking medium, gives the story a fresh perspective, and her dynamic with Joey is just as entertaining as it was between Rosa and him.

That said, the game is noticeably short, even by indie adventure standards. The puzzles are logical and well-integrated into the story but tend to be on the easier side, making it a fairly brisk experience. While the writing, music, and atmosphere are all top-notch, I couldnâ€™t help but wish there was a little more meat on the bones. Still, itâ€™s a must-play for fans of the series, hopefully setting the stage for whatâ€™s to come.

[quote]I accidentally reviewed the wrong Blackwell, meant to write this under the first one, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/magerama/recommended/80330/]Legacy.[/url] Yeah, a review inside a review that both link to each other, call it Blackwell Inception. But whatever, all of them are great anyway. This one has less reviews, so maybe it's for the best![/quote]
I'm quite an elitist when it comes to point & clicks, but I think that even in the 90's when there was plenty of competition the series would stand out. I'm even inclined to claim that Blackwell would be considered a classic by now. Because it has it all: charismatic characters with believable motivations, clever puzzles with original tools for solving them, and great stories with satisfactory conclusions. Not to mention the games get progressively more beautiful. Although, in terms of looks, my personal favourite is Unbound, a prequel. If I had to be a stickler, I'd say that the voice acting quality is not always consistent and I personally didn't care much for the music, but these aren't even nitpicks, only half-relevant whims. The two main characters, Rosangela the medium and Joey Mallone, a 1920's ghost who guides her, get so thoughtfully fleshed-out throughout the series your relationship with them is going to feel almost intimate. Together you shall investigate dead people's back stories and send their stranded souls to a place where they belong, not necessarily Heaven or Hell. That part remains a bit of a mystery. Not because the writing is obtuse, just subtle.

But what really makes these games stand out is the inventive use of Joey's intangible nature (ghosts are the perfect eaves-droppers, who knew?) and Rosa's notebook for puzzle-solving. Normally in adventure games you can either talk on certain topics or use inventory items to achieve your goals. Here, the notes add another layer of complexity. You can ask characters about the stuff you documented or compare evidence by using your records on environmental hot spots. You'll see what I mean almost instantly if you give Blackwell a chance. I think everyone should. There were no bad games in the series, each one of them is full of heart and soul. I truly enjoyed the whole thing and make my recommendation without a shadow of a doubt. I wish I could be more thorough, however, I played a long time ago. Don't have any notes left. So, these impressions are a residue that stayed with me after many years since I touched Blackwell. Which is probably also telling. The games never left my mind, haunting my ass into writing this. And you don't even have to be interested in the paranormal to love them. I'm not. These are still among the best point-n-clicks ever made. If you're into the genre and you just found this goodness, congratulations. It's your lucky day.

This was probably my least favourite entry in a while in terms of puzzles, but the story is so compelling and the characters so put-together that I hardly care. A good point and click adventure is one where you are challenged but the solution is achievable without a guide. Often times when you do break down and look up the answer, you feel embarrassed for not figuring it out yourself. This is not one of those games, it sucks. The puzzles REQUIRE a guide (which ruins the challenge) and finding items can be a pixel hunt. There are many great point and click adventure games, especially from the early 2000's. This is not one of them. | Runaway est une saga de point & click en 3 volets. Wir spielen ein ReporterpÃ¤rchen, das ein Event fÃ¼r eine harmlose Reportage besucht, dann aber in eine recht abstruse Geschichte hineingerÃ¤t, die zu verstehen mir leider nicht recht mÃ¶glich war.

Statt eines klaren Handlungsfadens (der ja meinetwegen RÃ¤tsel enthalten darf, die erstmal ungeklÃ¤rt bleiben) beginnt eine Achterbahnfahrt mit deplantierten Gehirnen, Teleportern und einer Pharaonin, um nur einige markante Sachen zu erwÃ¤hnen. Ich wurde nicht schlau daraus.

Ein typisches Point&Click: Sachen sammeln, zusammensetzen, einfÃ¼gen, sowie Dialoge duchgehen, die manchmal wichtige Informationen liefern. Eine positivere Sicht auf das Spiel findet man beispielsweise [url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198990784417/recommended/58570/]hier[/url]. | Twenty Twelve One Four

Ah, this game. I played it around 2012, I remember loving it, and now, a decade later, found that it is on Steam - and just couldn't resist getting it. And it is still absolutely delightful. 

The best thing this game has going for it is its' characters, Dan Murray and Liz Allaire, [i]especially[/i] Liz Allaire. She's insane in the most charming way. But Dan is amusing too - he's a jerk, but everyone around him still loves him anyway. And these two weirdos - and the overall insanity of the world around - give the game enormous amount of charm and humor.

Puzzle-wise game though the game is decently simple - though in a few times I had to either recall some vague memories of first walkthrough from back then, or just use in-game hint system, though most of the time the problem was in a missed hotspot.

There are a few issues with the game though. Sometimes it can be pretty glitchy - no idea if it's just from attempt to run an 2011 game on 2025 machine, or if it was glitchy from the start. Don't forget to save, so a sudden freeze didn't force you to replay last half of the chapter. Another issue - sometimes the pacing can be off, might be budget cuts or might be a stylistic choice, but a lot of the things are just shown through narration and smash cuts. And my main problem with the game, the main two leads share very little screentime, not enough to develop chemistry - which is weird considering how much the game ships them

But that's just a minor issues in the face of a very fun 7 hour experience | I love Pendulo's graphic style! A nice adventure but unfortunately with some illogical puzzles. | Bizzare adventure full of confusing puzzles (characters themselves sometimes comment on that), all kinds of references (bioshock one was my favourite), funny dialogues and fourth wall breaking. AprÃ¨s la conclusion de la saga Runaway, le studio sort en 2011 The Next Big Thing, qui est en rÃ©alitÃ© Hollywood Monsters 2 (il est dâ€™ailleurs sorti sous ce nom en Espagne).

Visuellement trÃ¨s joli, aussi bien au niveau des cinÃ©matiques dignes d'un dessin animÃ© que des phases de jeu, The Next Big Thing met Ã  nouveau en scÃ¨ne un duo homme / femme.

Nos deux hÃ©ros seront cette fois Liz Allaire : une jeune femme excentrique et un peu maladroite, sujette Ã  des absences soudaines oÃ¹ elle semble perdue dans ses pensÃ©es, et Dan Murray : un homme cynique et dÃ©sabusÃ©, amateur de sport et rÃ©fractaire aux intrigues absurdes.

L'histoire se dÃ©roule dans un monde dans lequel les monstres existent et sont des stars de cinÃ©ma. Liz et Dan sont envoyÃ©s en tant que reporters pour couvrir une remise de prix mais Big Albert, un robot gÃ©ant, a disparu et nos hÃ©ros vont mener l'enquÃªte.

Comme dans Runaway, nous avons affaire Ã  un duo trÃ¨s attachant et leurs personnalitÃ©s sont ici bien singuliÃ¨res. L'humour fonctionne bien et donne une motivation supplÃ©mentaire Ã  persister face aux Ã©nigmes les plus ardues. Le scÃ©nario est assez barrÃ© et devrait plaire aux fans des point & click de l'Ã©poque Lucas Arts.

The Next Big Thing est une trÃ¨s bonne surprise. Le studio a su proposer quelque chose de diffÃ©rent aprÃ¨s le succÃ¨s de la saga Runaway (mÃªme si, comme dit plus haut, ils avaient dÃ©jÃ  crÃ©Ã© cet univers avant). Un trÃ¨s bon reprÃ©sentant du genre !

Yesterday was a lot of fun, but it passed too quickly! | 60/100

A decent experience for a thrifty price. This game is a simple point and click adventure with the unusual treat of good attempts at story and characterization. I think the story itself might have been best served as a graphic novel for its linearity and also because it feels a bit incomplete. With gameplay functioning on logic, any off-the-cuff elements that betray the atmosphere of a certain location or puzzle always lead me to think that something was lost in translation, or could have been done a little better. 

On the technical side of things this game lacks polish. It is palpably low budget but decently crafted, with pleasantly drawn scenes and minimal 3d graphics. The music is quite good, but unfortunately does not loop properly. This leads to awkwardly quiet moments as there isn't much in the way of diagetic sound. 
 I was amused and never frustrated. But I was left feeling that a little extra development in the story, characters, and an extra few puzzle locations would make this game classic. Don't get me wrong, it's still super janky and awkward at times, but this stuff is better than it has any right to be. First however, to keep in theme with the game... 

==========
[i] FLASHBACK [/i]

I only vaguely remember how I got to know Pendulo Studios: I was looking at cheap games online and had always had an interest in adventure games. The game Vertigo caught my attention, because of the link with the film, and I looked up the developer on Wikipedia: a Spanish studio called Pendulo Studios. Charmed by their story of humble beginnings and passion for the medium, I made it a goal to try and play all their games (especially since the earlier ones frequently went on sale for less than 1 euro). I started out with their breakout hit Runaway and was convinced I understood their style: janky, weird and absurd stories without any depth but with a lot of heart.

Next I started with the sequel to Runaway, but it felt very similar and I noticed how my energy started to wane. The goal of playing all games by this studio quickly moved to my pile of canceled personal projects.

But during my initial plan I had been a bit enthusiastic: I had also cheaply bought one of their later games... Yesterday. As I have recently been going through an extra intense adventure games phase, I decided to give it a go...
==========

This game has the same jank and weirdness as their previous games. The dialogs are often ridiculous and some scenes don't make sense... But this game also does so many incredibly smart and innovative things I can barely wrap my head around it:
- Super engaging non-linear storytelling
- Incredible use of comic book style imagery during gameplay segments
- Fixes so many annoyances of adventure games: hotspots, hints, quickly fading the character to the target location instead of having them walk all the way...
- An incredibly complex story that actually kind of makes sense and is well constructed
- Puzzles with realistic solutions. One time I didn't believe a solution would work in real life, looked it up online and was even proven wrong!
- Packed with memorable scenes and beautiful environments
- Extremely high pace with zero filler

Runaway I liked [i]because[/i] of the weirdness and the jank.
Yesterday I admire [i]despite[/i] the weirdness and the jank.

I remember watching jacksepticeye playing it back in the day... Brought me a lot of nostalgia.
There's a pretty big item/description variety, but as this game is intended for kids there aren't any edgy/"NSFW" thing in the game, which could add a crap ton of comedic value to the gameplay.

7/10 | I grew up on Scribblenauts on the DS. Not a lot of content, not a lot of options-- honest to god, not really much of anything. Iteration on this series is what drove it to it's full potential, with Super Scribblenauts and beyond, all the way up to this. I truly think this is the definitive Scribblenauts, and while I hope one day yet another iteration will improve it further, this is a really solid sandbox title. | It's a decent game but it's missing a lot of QOL that it desperately needs.
It doesn't support windowed fullscreen, your only options are exclusive fullscreen or windowed.
When in windowed mode, you can't resize the window manually and resolution options are very limited.
There's no way to skip the tutorial section.
There's no way to skip most of the cutscenes, such as the ones that happen before every single starite mission, or the ones at the start of each new area, or the one after you die...

The gameplay is alright, but there's too many shards that boil down to "guy is hungry/bored/sick, give him a sandwich/book/doctor".

Game Name: The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav
Reviews:
There are components to the game that I find difficult to downvote if for no other reason then because people have put in work on them. It's not disjointed, it's not amateurish in the pure craft sense, people who did the technical parts of making this game knew their craft and do deserve to be paid and acknowledged for it. Occasionally the puzzles themselves were well done, and the dialogue system did show some courage in exploring how dialogues in point-and-clickers can be more than a sheet of linear/optional punchlines.

However, I found the whole thing to be unrelateable, mediocre, and at times uncomfortable. The love interest character, for example, is a fairy, sure, and you could justify her looks as being part of fairy folklore... but you're still playing a game where the love interest of the main character looks like a barely pubescent young girl. It's as if someone stuck a character drawin in anime style into a product done in a rather different style, and it's unintentionally kind of creepy.

Also, the setting felt exceptionally generic, so the whole thing fell flat even if I shrugged away the unfortunate choice of aesthetic in terms of the female lead. | Nice art style, OK-ish story, lot of bugs... it's kind of mid, really. For 2â‚¬ it's fine, for 20â‚¬ it's absolute garbage. | This is a pretty sweet game, even though the puzzles are not as complex and engaging as older games. In that regard it's more similar to Telltale games like The Walking Dead or Tales from the Borderlands: you will probably remember this game more for its story and narration than the puzzles themselves. | Ğ‘Ñ‹Ğ»Ğ¾ Ğ¸Ğ½Ñ‚ĞµÑ€ĞµÑĞ½Ğ¾ | Jogo Excelente

Game Name: The Lord of the Rings Onlineâ„¢
Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
Reviews:
2023 Update:

First major concern a lot of people have about LOTRO - is it dead?

(Still) No. It still has a very healthy playerbase, big enough that the even the RP servers feel populated. So don't let your worries about population turn you away. The numbers online are not always accurate, so I'd be wary of trusting outside reporting.

This is a classic MMORPG. It's going to be familiar to anyone that has played Everquest, DAoC, WoW, etc. While it means you're not getting any particularly amazing new mechanics, the perk is that LOTRO has figured out how to get the best out of those systems. Leveling feels well-progressed, classes are (mostly) balanced, and there is a lot of variety even within the classes to provide lots of replay value and ways to mitigate strengths and weaknesses.

LOTRO might have the best soundtrack I've ever heard. I recommend turning off battle music and just enjoying the compositions. Bree, as well as the various Inns and Halls located therein, have some fantastic scores attached to them.

Let's be honest though - if you play LOTRO you're probably here because it's Lord of the Rings. And in that regard, you will not be disappointed. The game is steeped in the lore - books and films - and has little nods to it scattered everywhere that are rewarding for someone that is really into their Tolkien scholarship. This is not a LotR skin thrown over a MMORPG framework - this is Middle Earth proper. Even with dated graphics (updates are coming soon, as of this writing) it's still a joy to look at. If you're rolling through some place like the Shire, you'll be able to soak in that sleepy, bucolic atmosphere that the movies portrayed so well.

This is a great MMO experience, and I usually find MMOs tedious. Moreover, it's free - so it's a low-commit to try it out for yourself. | å›½æœè€ç©å®¶å¼€æœç©åˆ°å…³æœï¼Œçˆ·çš„é’æ˜¥ï¼Œå…³æœåè¿™äº›å¹´å‰å‰ååä¸‹äº†ä¸‰æ¬¡ç¾æœåˆè¢«è‹±è¯­å’ŒåŠ é€Ÿå™¨åŠé€€ã€‚

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
Reviews:
I have been playing this game for years and only recently started playing it through steam. I would say my actual hours are probably closer to 2000. this is a huge, well established MMO with tons of content. if you like customized builds, look no further. you have the ability to create your character from the ground up. you choose where every ability, skill, feat and enhancement point goes, and you can even multiclass. ever wondered how an Archer Monk Wizard would fare in combat? Now you can find out. 

Quests are anything but the repetitive "find 12 of this". most quests have you go through intricate dungeons that have puzzle solving and traps and interesting story lines. while the game is less biased to balanced parties than it used to be, you will certainly reap rewards by teaming up with friends or other players although solo play is quite viable. 

The game is nearly infinite in how playable it is. once you reach max level you have a variety of options that allow you to continue improving your character by "reincarnating" back to a lower level, different class, etc in exchange for more feats, enhancements and ability points. as I mentioned earlier there is also a massive amount of quests and content to go through, and the devs regularly come out with more.

The game is free to play and I would say it is fairly free to play. expansion packs are the only things you have to purchase with real money (if you want them) other than that all the quest packs and quality of life items can be purchased through in game points that you gain from completing quests. I am very much against the pay to win trend you see in alot of f2p games and even paid games these days however this game is not one of those. if you get serious about the game you probably will put real money into it in order to buy the expansions or pick up some of the adventure packs you don't want to grind for but there are no lootboxes or gambling and everything is reasonably priced. Getting to max level as well as getting good gear is very achievable without paying anything. out of all the games I have spent time on, I would say this has actually been one of the least expensive when I compare how much enjoyment I have gotten out of it over time. If you are into MMOs and like excellent fantasy lore, challenging dungeons, highly customized characters and don't want to spend alot of $$$ for a full gaming experience, I would highly reccomend dungeons and dragons online. | This is one of the old school grouping favored MMOs that well, we just don't see anymore. This is not your World of Warcraft aka: Forever Quest for +Gooder items.  Items are meaningful, the world is huge and its D&D.

Excellent character building. D&D 3.5 is an amazing system.

Pros:
Old School feel
Grouping encouraged and easy
D&D 3.5
Traps matter
Excellent itemization
Excellent character building
Big Huge World with tons of content
Lot's of free content

Cons: 
Graphics a bit dated in some areas
D&D 3.5 can be daunting
The store is not pay to win, but can be costly. | I've played this for years and still have a lot of fun. New expansions and content constantly increase the play and variety. While a lot of content requires purchase or subscription, you can also earn points from playing that will allow you to purchase that same content. Admitedly the totally free route is much more of a grind, so you may find you want to purchase or subscribe for convenience. Overall a beautiful full 3D game, with movement in all directions including high altitudes and deep pits and water you have to swim through. There is day, night, rain, sunshine, multiple moons moving across the sky and beautiful sunsets. And yes, there be dragons too! There are a lot of areas, but you seldom have to run too far as there are telporters and guild ship docks all around to move you quickly to the various regions. Choose the difficulty that makes your play the most fun while still challenging - casual, normal, hard, elite and the new "reaper" mode. Many in-game Guilds welcome players - players' "renown" build up the guild and your character receives numerous buffs as the guild level increases. A rather unique feature in DDO is the ability to reincarnate. Tired of your current capped build? Have it start again from level 1, but stronger and better each time you reincarnate. While DDO characters only have 30 levels there are 5 sub-levels within each level. Each of these sub-levels or Action Points are roughly equivalent to a level in other MMOs, so it's comparable to 150 levels in other games. There are hundreds of quests to play either on your own, with your friends, with potential new friends, or even purchase an AI hirling to help out. The game starts in the D&D Eberron world, but has expansions to Forgotten Realms and soon Ravenloft. There are also questpacks for D&D modules Against the Slave Lords, Temple of Elemental Evil and Haunted Halls of Eveningstar. Normal quests have up to 6 players and raids have up to 12 players. There are so many ways to customize your character, You can even take multiple classes and try to combine benefits from both. But it's also fairly forgiving and if you make mistakes you can adjust the difficulty, rebuild your character or just wait and reincarnate into a better version. While the game has a lot of features, is very "learn as you go" and you don't have to do everything. E.g. Craft it you want or skip it altogether. Most of all I simply enjoy playing and experiencing the various worlds within the game. | Introduction;

I have spent many hours on this game over the years, and even though it may feel a little antiquated now, it is still one of the best RPG's that I have played in a very long time.

It feels like a true RPG, and a true adaptation of the AD&D Rule Set that true AD&D gamers are familiar with.  There is none of that level scaling crap in this game which has become a trend recently.  It is all leveled content.

This is one of the few games which I install every time I have to do a re-install of Steam for what ever reason.


The Game;


The world is huge, to be frank.  AD&D has access to areas of the Forgotten Realms region that, I assume most of us are familiar with, as well as the main city hub of Stormreach, and several huge explorer regions.  For instance, when you get into the Forgotten Realms Campeign setting, you gain access to Evening Star, and eventually gain the keys to the city. If you don't want to be there, then you can go to Stormreach, the Kings Forest, or even the Underdark.

The game has all of the usual enemies which you would associate with the AD&D world, including Dryads, Dire Bears, Kobolds, Druids, and Drow.  The enemies are plentiful, the loot is plentiful, and the traps which can be powerful enough to kill you in one shot, are also plentiful.  

It is a true AD&D game in every way.

The amount of loot that can be acquired from various quests is so expansive that I cannot list them all here, but there is everything from +5 Daggers, to +6 Docents, to +1 Kite Shields, to specific, named loot.  It turly is immense, and the amount of ways to get that loot is even more expansive especially considering the depth of the crafting system, and the wilderness areas which contain specific bosses who can be farmed for fat lewt.  On top of that, farmable item sets of great power can be farmed in Evening Star, simply by farming event tokens in the Kings Forest.  That only takes a few nights to get, and you are essentially fully geared.

The quests are plentiful for both groups, raids and solo players.  The main issue with that however, is that the servers can feel a little empty at the minute, but to help tackle this issue, the game does still receive constant new updates.  Later this year for instance (2017), the development team will be releasing the Ravenloft expansion pack.  Besides which, you can cut the need to do low level content out by purchasing the Shadowfell Conspiracy Expansion Pack and start from level 15 with a heroic class.  Furthermore, a lot of the content does not require a group, so there is nothing stopping you from playing solo, scene as every class has access to certain spell casting and healing items.  With all that said, the game is ageing well, for a 10 year old game.

The highlight of this entire game however, is the level of character customisation.  Every character can be specifically customised in a variety of ways, whether it is through the character generation screen when you first start, or through the epic destiny system, or the tallents trees.  

For instance I play a mage, that might sound boring at first, until you realize that I play a 20th level Eldritch Knight / Pale Master with 7 Epic Levels in Draconic Lineage.  That makes him one bad ass character in both melee and for spell casting.  The range of spells available are not only equal to anything in the original 2nd edition AD&D rule set, but also exceede it, because of these epic level spells and the abilities granted through the tallent trees.


Updates;


As I mentioned earlier, the game is constantly updated, and always in the right direction.  New raids, new quests, new player races are added, and a whole plethora of other things are usually added.  THERE IS NO NERFING which is important to mention, because the trend these days seems to be that if something is deemed too powerful, nerf it and that is usually your update in other games.  That doesn't happen in AD&D DDO.  Instead, we get new raids, new quests, new loot, new hero classes and races, in otherwords, content that we actually ask for.  It is all done right.  

I would highly recommend buying both of the available expansions packs however.  In particular, The Shadowfell Conspiracy DLC is well worth purchasing on F2P accounts.  If you plan to do some F2P gaming on DDO, especially as a solo player, without having to pay a subscription fee, buy that DLC pack before you do anything else.  I will tell you why below.

These are probably my two main gripes against the game.  

I don't like the fact that you may feel like you are forced to buy content packs to get the most out of the game if you don't want to subscribe to DDO, or want to treat DDO as entirely F2P, but you can work around this by buying the expansion packs instead.  

The only times that locked content may be a pain though, is if you are farming for specific loot, and that loot is only available in a certain part of the game world that you do not have access too, or when you may want to do a quest with your friends, and you don't have access to those quests because you haven't unlocked them.

My other gripe is that I really don't like how Spell Points are regenerated via Rest Shrines.  Rest Shrines can be used every 5 minutes, 15 minutes, or once only, depending on the difficulty setting.  This isn't a problem really for classes who don't use spells, but since many of us do, SP management becomes critical, and that is also the chief reason why I chose to play an Eldritch Knight.  Even when my toon runs out of SP, he can still go melee.  The SP elixers should also drop much, much more frequently in game, and I don't think that they should be listed on the store in all honesty.  Selling Spell Point recovery pots may be seen P2W, and may put potential new players off DDO.


Subbing Vs F2P.


don't bother subbing over a long period of time, it is not worth it.  The only real benefit to subbing is the "free" DDO store points that you get each month.  

There is a better, cheaper way to unlock most of the games content on F2P accounts, wihtout ever having to pay a subscription fee;

1:  Buy the Shadowfell Conspiracy Pack.  This will unlock a shit load of content and allow you to start from level 15, as a heroic class character.  This will also make a lot of the lower level, locked content worthless.

2:  Buy the Menace of the Underdark Pack.  This will unlock the Forgotten Realms setting as well as the Drow Race and Druid Class, and give you a permanent xp boost for your account.

3:  Use any store points given to buy the "Hall of Heroes pass" so that you can transfer between Eberon and Eveningstar without having to fight Lolth on a new toon each time.

Subbing for a year would cost well over $100.  Buying both of the expansion packs and the Hall of Heroes Pass costs around $50 and you will unlock a lot of the base games content.  you then have access to that content forever, without ever having to pay a subscription fee and can start a new toon at level 15, with access to those campeign settings instantly, forever.  


Conclusion.


I can whole heartedly recommend this game at the minute.  I am slightly nervous because news broke recently that the Development Team were teaming up with Daybreak Studios, which is a bad sign in my book, but still, I am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt, for now simply because I enjoy this game so much.  

IF DAYBREAK do anything to harm the success and longevity of this game, I will never have anything good to say about that business again, and I will probably hate them until the end of my days.

For now, I will continue to actively support this game, and I do plan to buy the Ravenloft Expansion pack later this year, if for no other reason than the goodies it should contain.  Hopefully, aside from the new content, it will include new heroic races, Experince Tomes, and DDO points.  

We shall have to wait and see though, how well this unholy alliance with Daybreak plays out. | In short: 
I strongly recommend this game WITH 2-4 friends in tow. Otherwise, given the current state of the community, I strongly recommend against it!

Note:
Some folks are having problems with becoming a subscriber or purchasing in the market. This is a problem with the Steam launcher. To circumvent, you need to go to your Steam folder ...\steamapps\common\Dungeons and Dragons Online\ and run TurbineLauncher.exe.


The long version:
I had thousands of hours of gameplay prior to acquiring on Steam. I have recently returned to check it out.

DDO, iirc, was the first Western mmo to go f2p-microtransactional. With Daybreak Games acquiring publishing rights recently, it's unclear how bad microtransactions will become. The claim is that DBG won't have undue influence, but this could easily be pushed into the P2W zone.

That said, DDO remains the "unique" mmorpg out there. Nuts-and-bolts it was built with grouping, suspense, problem solving, humor, quirkiness and discovery in mind, rather than grind or plain action. In its prime, it had 4 core group roles, with a nod to a fith: tank, healer, dps, trapper and a lil' bit control. The trapper was essential for finding and disarming invisible traps and unlocking key doors.

For newcomers who find a balanced and patient/dungeon-crawl group, the experience is unparalleled. DM narration, complex dungeon/mission mechanics (vs simple boss scripting), puzzles, and slower pacing really do rival your most acute PNP nostalgia.

Like all mmorpg's, however, the dev team has allowed this to degrade into solo'able content, or dps biased grouping. But unlike other mmo's, the original experience is still viable and worthwhile!

The graphics aren't 'modern,' but they have always had an ineffible charm.

Viscera Cleanup Detail is a fun game to play with friends or listen to something in the background if going solo. For a decade old game, it holds up on the fun factor and looks decent (recommend it on sale). 

That being said it's a shame the game runs poorly by default. To get the most out of the game (and its expansions) you'll need to manually adjust the fps. Go to steam\steamapps\common\viscera\engine\config\BaseEngine.INI (or from your library-properties-installed files-browse). Open this file with Word or Notepad and search for the following: 

bSmoothFrameRate=TRUE
MinSmoothedFrameRate=166 (game will bug if this goes beyond 166- adjust to your liking)
MaxSmoothedFrameRate=166 (game will bug if this goes beyond 166- adjust to your liking)

Now save the file and upon reopening the game you'll have better fps. Many thanks to Churo Zan for posting this in a Steam forum. | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ´ĞµÑ‚ÑÑ‚Ğ²Ğ°.

This game is the shit and the store description is quite honest. A bit grindy on first playthrough but progresses much faster on NG+. I enjoy it despite having played the later CSD games and appreciating their different mechanical approaches to the same dishes and events, and I don't think the three games are truly redundant. The game is written much more seriously overall than the later games as well, though that's saying surprisingly little and ultimately the story is inconsequential here.

Game is soundly assembled and balanced and all the dishes are worth consideration. You will build a lot of keyboard APM playing this game and memorizing combos for further optimizations, though I know of those who prefer joystick controls and are nonetheless quite skilled. 

Everything looks and sounds delicious, and almost inspiring, for drawings and exaggerated sound clips but yeah a lot of recipes get oversimplified. You're going to be cooking entire lasagnas and entire pots of soup for individual patrons. I recommend that you don't buy blue stars until you beat the game. | [i]Cook, Serve, Delicious![/i] in one word: FAAASTERRR

This game is full of keyboard action and plays a lot like those niche typing games. But instead of reading and typing words, you're reading dish orders and inputting corresponding hotkeys at blistering pace and superb accuracy. And yes, you can customize hotkeys for all the dishes, which is pretty sweet. However, there are some notable limitations: the key to serve a dish has to be Enter, and you can only use letters, so [];',. etc. aren't allowed.

Every day that you do well, you get "buzz", i.e. the game speeds up. There's no significant bonus related to this other than that you get more customers and earn more money. Most importantly, it makes the game speed fit your skill level. So this is just good game design.

The game also has great humor. If you stay a bit in the intro, you get people saying Cook, Serve, Delicious in every way possible. The e-mails you receive every day are full of character and humor as well.

All that is to say, these developers really know what they're doing, and I look forward to getting 100% for this game! | It's funny going back how much simpler this is than its sequels
Not that that's bad | Very fun and enjoyable typing game, that makes good use of ingenious mechanics to add complexity to an otherwise simple concept. I especially liked how some recipes created a different flow on the keyboard, while presenting unique challenges you had to overcome. 

(I only played on extreme so the experience might be different on normal)

Pros:
- simple and easy to navigate UI (there are some weird menu interactions like how you have to go to the "View/Buy Foods" tab to test recipes, but there aren't that many and you get used to it)
- straightforward gameplay that also needs a bit of strategy to play well
- good humor
- music
- diverse and fun recipe cards
- challenging (I wouldn't say it's especially hard but you need to be able to touch type to have a good time)
- not annoying to get all achievements

Cons:
- a few annoying bugs (mostly in the UI)
- becomes repetitive after a while (especially the final star rating)
- difficulty is somewhat inverse if you play on extreme because you don't have any upgrades in the beginning
 - you can't discard a dish to redo it if you failed (its annoying when you miss a perfect day because your hand slipped and added the wrong ingredient in a single soup from like 100+ orders) | A very fun game. It can get a little dull when you have low buzz and consequently very few customers, then the next day you'll be mashing keys like crazy to get through a mad rush. Cool music and overall a great experience.

A text-based adventure-style survival horror management game where you are the one running this monkey farm!

PROS
+ Cheap and compact
+ Generally fair but unforgiving difficulty
+ Minimalistic yet effective sound design
+ Clever, immersive TTRPG-inspired interface
+ Infinite replayability thanks randomly-generated playthroughs
+ Built-in editor to create your own custom survivours and adventures
+ Highly-engaging, if not downright addictive gameplay that perfectly encapsulates the tone and atmosphere of George A. Romero's "Day of the Dead"

CONS
- Only one save slot
- Five survivour limit
- Only three game modes
- Occasional Fallout 1-level interface jank
- "Zafehouse Diaries", not a particularly inspired title
- Half-baked relationship mechanic that feels very contrived at times
- Limited micromanagement options (e.g. no way to assign equipment to a specific character)

It would have been fun for the game making process to be deep with a lot of complicated variable.
Instead, it feels very generic, to the point were the optimal solution is akin to a formula.
For example, you try to make military game? Action is a good type choice.
Seek a console that makes good Action type games, and allocate your resource acording to the ACTION type games.
Yes... That's right, all action type games are all basically the same, you just need to find an approriate theme and a good work ratio for Graphics, Gameplay, Dialogues, AI, Audio, etc. FOR ALL ACTION TYPE GAMES.
So what if it's a shooter, a platformer, a music bit-mania type game, everything is the same if it's an action type game...
This makes the game overly simplistic, and frankly, a bit lazy in its design.
You shouldn't put all Action games, Strategy games, RPGs, Simulations games, and Adventure games into the same bucket. Shooters and Platformers are both Action games, but they are very different in their nature, and they are likely appreciated in different platforms.
Btw, PCs in this game are not the best for actions games, but in reality, they are the best for First Person Shooters, but not as good for other action games like platformers fighting games.
TLDR: I didn't like the game because it is a bit too generic, lacks real dept, and doesn't make sense in a real world context. | I remember when this game came out in 2013. 

How did I only get it in 2019?

And play it in 2025?

Excelente videojuego, una de las historias mas intrigantes e interesantes que esta gente ha traido, basado en los comics de la DC "Fables", The Wolf Among Us nos presenta una historia adulta sobre los personajes de las fabulas del aÃ±o de la rueda traidos a la Nueva York capitalista de hoy en dia, no lo vas a querer soltar hasta que lo termines, en mi opinion, el mejor juego de Telltale. | Really nice episodic mystery RPG. The narrative is interesting, engaging, and well paced. The art style and all the voice acting fit the narrative and themes nicely.  While linear, there's still a fair amount of variation that you can experience throughout the game. I got it on sale for $5 which is totally worth it, but after playing it, I wouldn't really have a problem paying the full $15. It's a great way to spend a weekend. | Last played through this game like a decade ago, it's a masterpiece. Play it if you haven't already.

ĞÑ‡ĞµÑ€ĞµĞ´Ğ½Ğ°Ñ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ½Ğ°Ñ Ğ¸ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ñ€Ğ¸Ñ Ğ¾Ñ‚ Telltale | This is a game that truly deserves a sequel, and Iâ€™m thrilled that Telltale has made a comeback. Hopefully, they can build on the vision of it.

Overall, The Wolf Among Us remains faithful to the vision of the comics especially in its world-building and character development, TT interwines these aspects masterfully with its signature storytelling style. I can confidently say this is the best game they have ever made. Itâ€™s a shame I played it so late. If youâ€™re hesitating to give it a try like I did for some reason, I strongly encourage you to play it.

Unlike Heavy Rain and other point-and-click adventure murder mystery games, this one takes a fresh and unique approach to the genre.

Bigby isnâ€™t just another clichÃ©, drunk, miserable cop. Based on your decisions, you truly feel like an important member of the Fable community and he proves to be more than a competent detective. Rather than simply focusing on unraveling a twist, the game lets you shape the main conflict in ways that have a major impactâ€”not just on Bigby himself, but on the entire city. This is what makes Bigby such a special and compelling character, you can truly feel the weight of his decisions, whether you choose to help others or ruin their lives.

Game Name: Scribblenauts Unmasked: A DC Comics Adventure
Reviews:
2018 getestet, ein Jahr spÃ¤ter getestet und in den letzten 2 Wochen. Leider bin ich sehr enttÃ¤uscht. Ich liebe diese Art von Spiel sehr und ich mag es das man sich kreativ ausleben kann.
Mir wird der SpaÃŸ nur leider ausgetrieben wenn mein Charakter stÃ¤ndig einfriert, Dinge verbuggt sind, die funktionieren mÃ¼ssten. (Z.B. eine Waffe erschaffen und als Adjektiv Kryptonisch, sie wird grÃ¼n und wenn ich sie Superman mit dem Schutzanzug gebe, verschwindet diese einfach. Erstelle ich aber eine Waffe direkt mit dem Adjektiv..was im Endeffekt doch das selbe ist, klappt es. Bei Der Quest hatte ich auch das Problem das ich stÃ¤ndig von Vorne beginnen musste, weil ich dann das Adjektiv ja schon genutzt hatte oder Superman die Waffe hat und nur in die Luft schlug...) Es war auf jeden Fall zum MÃ¤use melken. Ich hatte oft solche Probleme. 
Ich hatte viel Geduld, aber diese ist leider aufgebracht, fÃ¼r mich wird das Spiel als ,,nicht Spielbar'' gekennzeichnet und weggelegt. Ich hoffe fÃ¼r alle anderen das ihr nicht so Probleme habt. | Scribblenauts Unlimited is not just a game for me. it's a creative learning tool. I introduced this game to my sister and to my child as a way to make learning English early, engaging, and fun. It has its unique gameplay mechanics that allows players to type in almost any word and watch it come to life in a charming cartoon world.

My sister like it but my boy love it and still play it till 8 years old. He finish the game many times. 
I am really thankful to this game. This game really made learning english fun for many child with english as second language. | Pros:
+ Gameplay is fun
+ Lots of DC Comics Characters to choose from
+ Performance is great and visuals are slick
+ Ambitious Soundtrack
+ A great amount of maps to play on
+ Many Objects and Adjectives to use from Maxwell's Notebook

Cons:
- Some Story Missions are confusing | Scribblenauts Unmasked: A DC Comics Adventure is the ultimate geek crossover, blending the chaos of Maxwellâ€™s magical notebook with the sprawling, lore-rich universe of DC Comics. As a hardcore DC fan and collector, this game feels like an all-you-can-eat buffet of Easter eggs, obscure characters, and deep cuts from the comics. Want to summon Ambush Bug? Go for it. Feel like pitting Anti-Monitor against Mogo the Living Planet? The game has you covered. Itâ€™s not just a gameâ€”itâ€™s a celebration of everything DC, lovingly rendered in charming, blocky graphics. It even manages to sneak in a little education for kids (and some adults), teaching them English vocabulary while they accidentally learn the difference between Pre-Crisis Superman and Post-Crisis Superman. Genius, really.

For die-hard DC fans, the sheer depth of the character roster is both mind-blowing and a badge of geekdom. The game isnâ€™t just about Batman, Superman, and Wonder Woman (though theyâ€™re here in spades); it also includes Nth Metal, Starro, and, yes, even Kite Man. Hell yeah! Itâ€™s the perfect sandbox to explore the DC Universe in hilarious and unexpected ways. Watching Mr. Mxyzptlk summon chaos or solving puzzles with Alfred Pennyworth wielding a giant wrench never gets old. And for younger players, itâ€™s a crash course in DC mythology wrapped in fun, creative problem-solving. For us seasoned fans? Itâ€™s a gleeful tribute to the stories and characters weâ€™ve obsessed over for years. Scribblenauts Unmasked isnâ€™t just a game; itâ€™s a geekâ€™s dream come true. | Just some good wholesome clean fun.

serinin 2. oyunu Ã¶zellikler aynÄ± hikaye biraz daha geniÅŸ ama ilk oyunun tadÄ±nÄ± vermedi gerilim hat safhada | Black Plague is a direct sequel to Penumbra:Overture, with some small but welcome improvements.

You make your way through a secret research complex, that is more detailed and interesting than the mines in Overture. The combat system is completely removed, which is probably for the best.

Story is much more engaging and has some interesting twists. The only thing I didn't like was a couple of cheesy jumpscares (like body falling in front of you out of nowhere...) and some small visual glitches in the last chapter. Other than that, I had fun from start to the end.

Black Plague shows that the developers recognised the issues of the first game and tried to improve on them while keeping the good things intact. Definitely recommended if you like the original. | "Black Plague" is a continuation of the first "Overture" game of Penumbra. Continue your journey through the mines deep under the snowy land of Greenland and reveal its dark and terrifying secrets what's burred in there. Have you got enough of the spirit to survive? | Massive improvement over Overture, featuring almost zero direct combat! A direct sequel to the aformentioned game. Story is, as always, amazing while everything else is alright at most.
Also: I have no idea how the laser disarm minigame works, randomly hitting buttons seems to work but I don't think it's the inteded solution.


Bonus - Penumbra: Requiem review.
I wouldn't recommend playing requiem unless you really like puzzles, like, REALLY like puzzles. It does not add much, if anything, to the story. Also, Requiem is not scary, as in, it doesn't try to be. So if you expect it to be another stealth oriented horror game with puzzles like the previous titles, don't. | A perfect sequel that addressed the shortcomings of Overture and exceeded my expectations.

It's a short expansion for the Black Plague focused mainly on puzzles, which are mostly fun and not too difficult. The main thing which made me keep moving forward was to find out how the Penumbra story ends.

The atmosphere is little bit ruined by the fact that the levels have no logical connection to each other and the it all feels like a series of random puzzle levels. Also, the first person platforming sucks.

If it weren't for the story, I probably wouldn't recommend it. | Only play if you want to know more of the story and what happened to Philip, otherwise it's just a Portal game lacking all the survival elements of the previous games. | Weakest game in the trilogy.
