Game Name: Castle: Never Judge a Book by its Cover
Reviews: Decent game. I skipped one puzzle, which I rarely do, so it has to really suck for me to do that. The storyline was pretty easy and straightforward. the puzzles were hit or miss. story was ok, but a lot of characters, so it got confusing. I've never watched the show and I enjoyed the game just fine. I completed it in one sitting.

Game Name: Small Town Terrors: Pilgrim's Hook Collector's Edition
Reviews: Interesting story, nice gameplay. | It's very good!!!

This was just the perfect game. Had everything I was looking for. A storyline, a mixture of hidden object scenes and thinking games. Once I figured out how to use the map...(Silly me) it went a lot faster then having to click back all the time. 

Not everything is obvious and I had to peek at a few walk throughs to figure one or two things out, but over all it was a good time waster. My son enjoyed watching me play it and helped me as well. 

I will be buying other titles of this as well. I really enjoyed it. | This is the fourth game in this series, and the closest to a sequel of the first game House 1000 Doors: Family Secrets. (I have played all 4 games in the series, in order.)  It is stand alone, as is, but the series storyline might confuse a player as the game briefly refers to previous game adventures in single "throw away/reveal" lines depending on how much of the series storyline is known.

The story: The Palm of Zoroaster, a cursed orb, has been destroying things, people and quite possibly civilizations (or at least, select parts of it) for centuries.  Your job is to destroy the orb.  (No spoilers because there are some if one has been following the series storyline.)  Learn the orb's history, witness its destruction, and of course discover how to destroy it and gather the means to do so.  

The game is set up with an introduction/tutorial, four adventure chapters, and the final conclusive chaper.  I rather like this setup which is different then other HOs with a much more linear storyline.  What changed in this game from the first game (Family Secrets) is the player does not get to choose which adventure to embark on first.  For this game and storyline purposes it is perfect though.  

Hidden object scenes, mixed with some head scratching puzzles and the usual standard puzzles, plus some point and click and a chapter by chapter accumulate and use inventory.  Nothing too hard or tear your hair out challenging.  Game comes with a walkthrough the player can access if they get stuck in game or on a puzzle.  Every puzzle has a skip option and sparkles on needed objects or mini puzzle scene.  Unless playing in Hard mode.  There are three game modes available, in-game achievements, wall papers and a bonus chapter.

Warning: If you are hunting for those elusive extra "hidden/ghost/shape shifting" objects make sure you have them all before leaving the introduction or adventure chapter because you cannot go back once the chapter is finished. (Except in a new game).

Opinion: I like the series, therefore I like each game.  The overall concept is interesting and lends itself to innumberable further games.  The only thing I did not like in this game was the end.  I was expecting a much longer cut scene.  It ended and I thought "Wait, that is it."  The adventure ended, the game ended, but the end felt truncated.  Ah well the bonus chapter made up for the abrupt conclusion. | ç³»åˆ—ç¬¬äºŒéƒ¨çš„ç‚¹å‡»è§£å¯†æ¸¸æˆ

ç•Œé¢ã€å¯¹è¯ã€æ”»ç•¥ç•Œé¢éƒ½æ±‰åŒ–äº† | Evil has taken over at the House of 1,000 Doors since your last visit. It's up to you to travel through dimensions again to save everyone and particularly Gabriel, the protector of it.

This game is the sequel to House of 1,000 Doors: Family Secrets and you'll find some familiar characters, if not everyone from the first game. The plot is also a good written. You're going from China to the jungle, which means many exotic backgrounds for someone who is used to a western city.

The gameplay is the usual one: click on items that you'll need in another scene, solve puzzles, find hidden objects in specific areas, etc.. I found everything well-balanced. Also, you have close-up views in these hidden objects scenes and some objects you can move as they're also hiding items to find.

But what made me love the game, though I've hinted it earlier, is probably the journey through 4 different worlds and meet people that knew about Gabriel - I found it nice that the guy has a background, though it's breaking the charm around this mysterious man (but the more is known in the bonus chapter). And the scenes are really well drawed. You're really transported into other worlds.

The soundtrack is also nice but didn't change from the previous game.

So if you're a fan of HOG, you have to own this game. Besides, there are trading cards with nice emoticons and backgrounds. | â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜† - hodnocenÃ­ v rÃ¡mci Å¾Ã¡nru Hidden object

[h2] Score: 8/10 [/h2]

If you're like me then you absolutely love watching these lost place and urban explorer videos. Likely, you have also seen such a video on an abandoned hospital or perhaps even an asylum. If so, you're already pretty well prepared, because this time it's not empty or abandoned; quite the other way around. Outlast, released back in 2013 by Red Barrels delivers a combination of these sorts of videos and horror. 

Taking on the role of a daring journalist, you head out to Mount Massive Asylum, out in the middle of nowhere. Armed with nothing but a whistleblower document, informing you about the horrific human experiments supposedly taking place inside the asylum, and your trusty camcorder, equipped with a night vision mode. This camcorder is the heart of the game and what makes it stand out. You will witness almost the entirety of the game through the screen of that thing, making it feel like a collection of found footage. You'll need the night vision to navigate the dark areas of the Asylum, which will burn your battery life, so collecting AA batteries is a top priority. 

Outlast is less of a game and more of a test of your fight-or-flight response - think of it more as hide-and-seek game on the hardest difficulty. Except the seeker is a bloodthirsty lunatic and there is no happy ever after if they happen to find you. You can't fight back; you either run away or hide, or accept your fate, and that's where the beauty of this game lies. It lies in those hopeless moments you run away from a group of lunatics, not knowing where to go and asking yourself "what next?". It's hiding behind a desk and debating on if it's better to stay hidden or just send it. Those moments when you're perfectly thought out plan fails and the chase music starts playing, your heart pounding as you run aimlessly through the halls trying to shake off your pursuer.

The gameplay is what kept dragging me back into this horrible Asylum. The rush of adrenaline when you see something glowing in the corner of your camcorder, in the darkest possible place, and have to ask yourself if it was an enemy or nothing. This game lives from the sections of the game that are not scripted. Those sections that change every playthrough due to the AI's and your own behaviour. It's extremely immersive and strong enough to make you forget that it's all just a clever combination of 1s and 0s on a screen. 

The game is split up into 3 (4, counting cutscenes) major gameplay elements.

1) Exploring 
Usually the most atmospheric, and serve as breather sections. You find documents that elaborate the lore, recharge your camcorder using batteries and witness the still horrors of the asylum.

2) Chase
Intense yet scripted chases. They give you a good kick most of the time and make you feel desperate. They're extremely well made using little tricks that keep the tension high. Like climbing, squeezing through gaps, or my favorite, doors that open toward you. 

3) Freeroam Objectives
Intense but sadly very repetitive. You are set out into a wider, open area with a set of goals and an enemy. Like, for example, turning the power back on, which requires switching on three seperate levers. These are genuinely great, since like mentioned before, the way these go down change practically everytime depending on your playstyle and the AI's tendencies. 

Some other noteworthy things to praise are the length, story/atmosphere and especially soundtrack. The game doesn't overstay its welcome and ends in about 3-5 hours. Which is a pretty good length. It stops before it gets repetitive. 

Outlast's atmosphere is crazy good. Thanks to the soundtrack and just general atmospheric work. The camcorder records every bit of dust in the air, the sounds are great, you almost always hear distant screams and cries, steps or people banging on doors. Every chapter has a distinct environment and i feel has a nice creative twist; like the dark sewers, where your every step in the water can be heard, or the prison, where you'll be nice and close to all these lunatics in their cells. Additionally, this shit is also (almost) entirely based on a true story! So if you're interested, you can do some research on the game's topics after you finish. It's worth it. And whether you are slowly stepping around the foggy courtyard, or being chased by the big fat guy, the soundtrack perfectly illustrates these moments. Seriously, the soundtrack deserves a michelin star and is overlooked so often.

Sadly, when there is no apparent enemy around, the game does rely heavily on jumpscares to keep the horror part alive. These.. are fine but a) you only fall for them once and b) they are all verryyy similar. You're almost always jumped at by a patient accompanied by an over the top scream. But it also has some genius scares that i wont go into ;).

Over all, i think even 11 years after launch it's still well worth it. Though not at full price, get it at a discount. Like most games it's usually on sale about every 1-2 months. It'll definitely keep you entertained and occupied for a while.

Game Name: Game of Thrones - A Telltale Games Series
Reviews:
What has to be one of the most miserable, disappointing and pointless games out there. Almost every episode builds up to something that is quickly resolved in the most awful way imaginable or just goes nowhere. Choices matter even less than usual with this one, too. Even if you're a big GoT fan like I am, waiting for GRRM to finish those books or Chinese water torture might be a more enjoyable use of your time. | Finally finished this miserysimulator after forcing myself to play it. Most choices dont seem to matter and just leads to the characters getting punished, humiliated or killed. The creators clearly thought that what makes Game of thrones is just alot of misery and carnage and little else. I'm glad this is over so I can uninstall and try to forget. | Game of Thrones: A Telltale Game Series â€“ A Tale of Betrayal (Both in Story and Development, and Also in Availability)
If thereâ€™s one thing Game of Thrones taught us, itâ€™s that life is cruel, unfair, and no one is safe. Fittingly, Game of Thrones: A Telltale Game Series delivers that same gut-punchâ€”not just in its story, but in the fact that it ends on a massive cliffhanger that will never be resolved because of the ill-fated collapse of Telltale Games.

But hey, that doesnâ€™t really matter anymoreâ€”because you canâ€™t even buy it on Steam. Like so many characters in Game of Thrones, this game was brutally erased from existence, delisted from the store with no chance of return. Unless you already own it or find some alternative means of playing, itâ€™s as good as gone.

Not that you'd be missing much in terms of agency. Telltale was famous for making you feel like your choices mattered, but letâ€™s be honestâ€”they donâ€™t. No matter how cunning or careful you are, the story mostly funnels you down the same miserable path, with only minor differences in who dies now versus who dies later. Itâ€™s Game of Thrones, after allâ€”everyone loses eventually.

And yet, despite all that, itâ€™s still an engaging ride. The writing, voice acting, and atmosphere feel authentic to the show, and the tension keeps you investedâ€”right up until the final episode drops a brutal cliffhanger that will never be answered.

Very impressive environments and worldbuilding, ending feels a bit rushed, but its a really engaging journey | Shardlight undenaibly a good retro Indie point & click game.

Wadjet Eye Games once again delivers a decent product.
A simple story with good writing, grounded characters with nice voice and smart puzzles.

A post-apocalyptic world going through the usual genre cliches, but hey,
it is still very endearing as we live through the perspective of a simple but ingenious citizen.
There are no magic, mutants or demons in this game. Just the good old post-apolacypse setting.

The puzzles were surprisingly logical and well designed,
meaning no insane moon logic or developer tunnel vision (as is common in the genre). Quite Enjoyable!
(Everyday I thank we don't get another Sierra or Lucasarts game..)

From what I read, the ending was polarizing for some but I liked it.
How it tested where your ideologies stand, good thing I got the "good" ending.


Shardlight is a decent entry.
I liked it. | Great pixel art, voice acting, puzzles. Would recommend! | A beautifully grim take on the post-apocalyptic, [u]Shardlight[/u] excels at the key aspects of point-and-click adventures. The story is dark and compelling, and I always knew how to progress. The characters are intriguing; I felt sad for the good ones and righteous when the villains got their due. The puzzles challenged me, but I enjoyed solving them. The voice acting, especially the protagonist, stood out. The games from Dave Gilbert (Wadget Eye) and Francisco Gonzalez (Grundislav Games) have become familiar to me for a long time and incredibly interesting adventures, historical and serious stories. This game was no exception, but it occupied a special place. A slight nostalgia and sadness, as if in search of an important lost thing, trying to return and correct it, is inherent in the young heroine Amy, suffering from a serious illness, who needs to gather all her strength and solve a lot of issues both for herself and to save the future. delve into political intrigues, raise the question of faith - what and how much, and, together with other heroes of the game, go a long way. High-quality pixels and interesting quests do not let you get bored, the game is long and takes you into the universe of an alternative future, which may be very close...Bravo to the creators!

Really enjoyed this game. Will have to get the other Wadjet Eye games as well, I believe this is the first one I've played by them but this was really well done. Gameplay wise it's a pretty simple point and click game, kind of a streamlined version of the old school point and click games, which I liked.

Story was very good, the voice acting was excellent and for me is what really brought everything together. After playing through several times, this game is more like a good book that you get to know the characters, was a bit sad to reach the ending the first time, but the story was nicely wrapped up. Hopeful for a sequel still, even though it's been several years. | Curto, mas profundo. Trata histÃ³rias com maturidade e de forma extremamente criativa. RecomendaÃ§Ã£o absoluta para qualquer um que gosta de mistÃ©rio. | Started kinda slow, but really picked up.

It has a pretty good story and a good ability to make impactful choices.

Although it was mostly simple, there were some creative challenges that made it enjoyable. | A real demonstration of what this engine can do. Great writing and beautiful visuals, truly top Dave Gilbert and Wadjeteye work.

[b]An intimate diary tribute to the 10th anniversary of Maxâ€™s journey.[/b]

It used to be a tradition for me to play [i]Life is Strange[/i] every New Yearâ€™s Eve when visiting my childhood home. So many memories intertwine with it. Jumping up and down on the bed losing my mind after the 3Ep twist. Bugging my classmates with a basket of theories and insane lore about the game's development. Cutting my hair slowly bit by bit until it eventually resembled Max's. I learned Spanish Sahara by heart and played it non-stop on the ukulele I begged my parents to buy. Even the wall of my room was decorated in Max's style â€“ a tradition I carry to all the homes, or the resemblance of homes, I've changed along the way. In 11th grade, I made Maxâ€™s journal from scratch, it was one of my favorite pieces in the room, taking a notable place among my own personal and school diaries. I remember playing the 4th episode on a school week until 6am and going straight to school all hyped and simultaneously out of it. When Episode 5 came out, I sobbed for two weeks! My best friend at that time and I woke up so early that day, purposefully missed school, and spent all day immersed in that final chapter â€“ her watching a live stream and I cursing at my old computer unable to handle Maxâ€™s time jumping shenanigans; of course, taking occasional breaks for comparing our declining emotional stability. [i]Life is Strange[/i] carried me from that final school year straight to University, helping me figure out some stuff about my own life along the way; as it did to many. Every time I turn it on now it just turns into a crying fest. From love, of course. But also sorrow.

Over the years, Iâ€™ve read so many players' intimate recollections prompted by the game's content; random snippets of peopleâ€™s most vulnerable life stories sprinkled over each social media platform. Simply something awoken in people of all ages and backgrounds, perhaps by the gameâ€™s mellow nostalgic aesthetics and unabashed willingness to attune to the finest memories and emotions of our hearts. It was rather pleasant to witness the resurgence of [i]LiS[/i] fandom in late 2024, collectively reminiscing on our intimate interaction with the story, the newfound change in perspectives, and the passionate desire to mutually share all the warmth we still have for its characters. 

Living through Max was foundational for me, a self-conscious girl growing into confident adulthood with innocence violently ripped away from her. It was simply an average coming-of-age process, growing up and seeing a world from a different perspective, learning to connect and empathize with those around, learning from them and finding our own flaws and desires, recognizing them and growing to be better. But also a darker experience of going through my own sexual assault, of losing my own innocence, shifting and modifying the self to perhaps be more cynical and pragmatic, of maybe seeing the world through a darker yet necessary lens. Yet, ultimately, all of it forming one unified identity that is nevertheless a beautiful landscape of variable experiences and lessons; adulthood. I will always love the character of Max dearly. I will always cry noticing the gradual change of her vibrant diary doodles to objective, subdued in color entries with each passing chapter. I will always cry for the innocent love Max finds in non-innocent circumstances. The exploration of Maxâ€™s fractured mind following the violation will always mean the world to me, back in 2015 making me feel seen and motivated to start my own tumultuous journey of healing. I will always be grateful for Donâ€™t Nod creating this beloved gamified companion to project our own internal worries onto, our transformations, and dreams; to reach intimate answers through a bittersweet, meditative experience.

[i]Life is Strange[/i] maintains sheer gratitude and wonder for each part of our environment while not rejecting the truth of the shadows stretching over the worldâ€™s corners. Finding beauty in the industrial powers of small towns, their nature, expansion in infrastructure, transformation of beliefs, unique differing people, and their interconnected messy ties to each other: as colleagues, students, friends, lovers. Finding beauty in the contrast of lives cut short, resentments, domestic disputes, destructive truths, violence, and uncertainty of tomorrow. Creating a living, breathing town that wishes to continuously evolve, grow, and adapt to the changing population making up its geographical landscape. Rachel Amberâ€™s character is perhaps the most compassionate interpretation of Laura Palmerâ€™s image I have seen, Chloeâ€™s uncensored journey of clawing through grief calls to the most helpless moments of my own 19old self, and the understanding of violence captured in a human-shaped form still wounds me deeply: of course, so much of [i]LiS[/i] was inspired by and carried love for David Lynchâ€™s legacy.


It's not so much the content of media; over time it becomes something bigger than its key narrative points. Rather, the events it accompanied in life, the memories you associate it with. That's when stories become truly dear to the heart no matter the years passed. It simply evokes a subdued feeling, like a thread granting the privilege to time travel to your own thoughts, memories, tastes, smells, relationships, places.

I tried replaying this game in so many locations now it can be drawn onto a map, like a shi+ty road trip. But I never lasted very long, about 30 minutes before I lose my cool completely and start thinking of the hand-drawn picturesque walls of my school. Of the captured memories sprinkled over my walls. Of the path to my home from school, from my friends, from the center, from my mom's job, from the park, from the waterfront. Of the last school days and giving away my books. Of getting closer with my classmates and finally understanding how similar we are. Of looking out my window, the windows of my friends, the windows of my school â€“ and seeing sunsets, sunrises, golden hours, whirlwinds, blizzards, screeching hot days. Of dark days. Of town spots I avoid. Of town spots I wish could stay with me. A living breathing townâ€¦ trapped in hazy, fleeting pieces of memory. Out of reach, a resemblance of something that used to be, overwritten by new places and people â€“ when it's one of the last anchors you have to that past you cannot go back to. Learning to hold the value of delicate memory, accept darkness, and cherish its lighter undertones.

Finally replaying the game after these years, Iâ€™ve been finding new connections with Arcadia Bay, of the radical shift it makes from a nostalgic warm town to a harbor of ruin. How it strongly encompasses both, yet neither. Iâ€™ve been thinking of how the geography of my town has been modified, its prior identity forever wiped away. Iâ€™ve been countering the grief of losing childhood physically and emotionally with the fleeting traces of glee that used to be. On dark days, I will always hold on to the memory of sitting on the hot-to-the-touch boulder stone with my childhood friend, giggling about our new life developments, surrounded by forestry of a quiet park and bright sun. Of looking around me and seeing kids become more expressive in their identities, unafraid to look, think, and love however they please. Of regularly visiting my school and checking in to see if the asphalt drawing we made in dedication to our class teacher has faded away, or the chamomiles covering the schoolâ€™s entrance are still greeting the children. Of peaking outside from the large plants covering my momâ€™s windowsill and seeing the rose we have planted outside slowly rise and bloom. Of always having a prepared 2h15m playlist to accompany me on the trip to my town from the nearby big city.

Nowadays, [i]Life is Strange[/i] transports me to the hot summer days of my home. 
I will always be grateful for having a chance to time travel. | I've been wondering for a long time whether "Life is Strange" is a game I could recommend or not, since it has very positive reviews and a slew of fans. I also expected such an experience. Unfortunately, I have to admit that the game disappointed me. Don't get me wrong, I fell in love with the demo version (chapter one), which promised an elaborate crime story with several suspects and lots of decision-making. We were introduced to the characters along with our heroine (Max), as she was new to the school. It promised a story full of excitement, mystery and consequences of our choices.

Unfortunately, after purchasing the full version of the game, with all the chapters (21 hours played), the spell faded in several different ways:

1. The game turned out to be a delusion of the consequences of the choices (except for the final decision at the end - although this one is disappointing in terms of the logic of the choice and the realization of the consequences, especially in the case of one final).
 
2. The game deliberately distracts us from some characters, completely forgetting them as criminal suspects. Because of this, we are unable to gather evidence in their case. Which is then supposed to cause surprise, shock, etc. - A cheap, ineffective ploy.

3. Overly cinematic final chapters. At one point in the game, there was so much story told in interludes and stills that for most of the chapter, the player had nothing to do but minor linear activities that contributed nothing. This killed my immersion and and even more my sense of control and decision-making.

4. Little bugs. The ending cutscenes have a number of close-ups of characters talking without their mouths moving. There are so many of them that at some point it becomes uncomfortable. The time reversal system is also sometimes unintuitive and can erase a decision even though it was not intended.

**[Warning: little spoilers]**

5. Final decisions: It is supposed to arouse emotions, but whether it does so is not necessarily the case. The first ending looks good and emotional, but the second one is dull and bland. In addition, it shows that everything we did throughout the game is irrelevant to our protagonist Max (all the friendships we've made, the lives we saved, etc.). That's not how you write good endings.

6. Imbalance in the characterization of the characters. Just as most of the characters are good written (they have their own motives, secrets, behaviors and are believable), I cannot say the same about two of the main characters who should arouse sympathy - Chloe and (maybe) Warren.
The friendship between Max and Chloe is, in my opinion, completely one-sided. Chloe uses Max's skills like a toy, she doesn't accept criticism, she's explosive and I didn't get the impression that she actually cared about her friend or even respected her, her character and way of being. Thus, he forces her to engage in various activities, even though Max points out that such activities are not to her liking or even can hurt her. Despite this, Max keeps repeating wonderful words about lifelong friendship and can also create a love bond with her. The only positive aspect of Chloe's character is at the end, when she realizes all these elements and talks about them, and makes her first unselfish decision.
As for Warren, he's written strangely. He's supposed to be a geek with a crush on Max, and he basically is, but throughout the entire game I had the impression that there was something strange about him and that he was hiding something. | æ²‰æµ¸æ„Ÿæ— æ•Œï¼Œå‰§æƒ…ä¸æ‹–æ³¥å¸¦æ°´ï¼Œå°±æ˜¯å…‹æ´›ä¼Šåƒä¸ªå•¥å¸ï¼Œçœ‹åç»­å‰§æƒ…å‘å±•å§ | This is one of the best video game stories ever told â€“ a true classic. Picture this: youâ€™re dropped into an island with nothing but your wits, some rocks, and a stick, and youâ€™ve got to figure out how to stay alive while dodging massive carnivores and attempting to avoid becoming someone elseâ€™s dinner. Add in some players who think theyâ€™re the islandâ€™s top predator (spoiler: theyâ€™re not), and suddenly, your quest to survive turns into an all-out, hilarious game of â€œwho can mess with who first?â€ Trust me, itâ€™s intense, but also surprisingly fun when you realize youâ€™re a second away from being eaten by a T-Rex and you somehow make it out alive. Thatâ€™s when the real fun begins!

At its heart, ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a battle royale-style game set in a prehistoric world, filled with dangers both natural and player-made. The basic premise? You, along with other players, are dropped onto a hostile island where you must gather resources, craft weapons, tame dinosaurs, and try to survive long enough to become the last one standing. The twist? Youâ€™ll need to strategize, team up, or even betray others to outsmart and outlast the competition. Itâ€™s not just about surviving the creatures; itâ€™s about surviving the players too. Tame some raptors, build traps, create defenses, and get ready for combat because the last survivor on the island wins. Oh, and donâ€™t forget about the giant mutant spiders and those terrifying, unkillable bosses roaming around. In short, everything wants you dead, and you have to be smarter, stronger, and faster to avoid becoming dinner.

What really stands out about ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is the blend of survival mechanics, strategy, and chaotic multiplayer action. The vast array of creatures you can tame and use in combat adds layers of complexity to the gameplay. The game rewards strategic thinking, from deciding when to team up with others (and when to stab them in the back) to figuring out the best way to hunt or avoid the islandâ€™s mega-predators. The crafting system is deep, and the thrill of gathering materials to build your base and weapons while fending off enemy tribes is incredibly satisfying. If youâ€™re into survival games with a high stakes, high tension environment where every decision countsâ€”and where a single mistake could lead to an epic failureâ€”ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a must-try. Itâ€™s perfect for anyone who loves a challenge, epic dino battles, and the thrill of outlasting other players in a hostile environment. Why can't you connect pieces to each other?  Why can't you change the cut of puzzles?  Why is the DLC, which must be nearly no cost to "develop," so expensive per image?  And WHY, if all the game does is puzzles, do the images seem to have no thought behind them as to what makes an image fun to assemble?

In summary, why would I invest in a bunch of DLC when someone could easily put a better jigsaw puzzle game on Steam and I literally would have no reason to ever come back to this mediocre option again...

...and now I think someone did.  I'm going to check out Super Jigsaw Puzzle: Generations.

[h3]Broken[/h3]
Sadly, and I cannot believe that these games get onto the store, but the game is just a bit broken.
Saves do not always save, and there is no way to bypass the intro screens later on.
Developer has not responded to issues for years, not worth the trouble. 

A pity, because the game does work, story is interesting ,but it's abandoned and janky.

Such a great point & click game. I finally got around playing this game since I bought it a decade ago (2016 I just checked my purchase history!). I'll start by saying this game has a strong narrative and not so convoluted puzzles. Not once did I feel like having to randomly combine items to progress or trying to solve some mind-boggling puzzles that required me to look up a guide. The story was creepy and full of lore and great characters. The voice acting was superb (Jim Sterling voiced this!), plus the game allows you to manually save in case you're one of those achievement hunters. There's supposedly a sequel to this game with how they ended it but it's currently stuck in a development hell for years, plus the developer himself is sick in real life. So let's pray and hope for the best... | Story was okay. Probably could have skipped the very short middle story, it didn't add much. Had enough of the inventory collecting and puzzles of where to put something to make it a quick P&C romp. Get it on sale for sure. | I enjoyed this horror-themed point-and-click adventure game.  It consists of three chapters that each take about an hour to complete.  The puzzles are VERY straightforward, so I wouldn't recommend it for people who are looking for a challenge.  But the story is creepy (especially the third chapter) and the voice acting is above average.   Overall the game is quite engaging and its a nice way to spend an afternoon.  It ends with a cliffhanger, and the sequel was never released, so skip this one if you want closure.  Definitely worth it if you get it on sale.  6/10. | pixel grafik point click bulmaca hikaye 3 farklÄ± hikaye mevcut ortalama bir yapÄ±m | Very interesting game with weird twists - as much as I had no idea where it was going, I loved this game! (Also I'm a massive fan of pixel graphics hehe)

[*]Unnecessary experience grind for skills and buildings
[/list]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3401267474
[b]Lots of fun moments[/b]
Honestly, I didn't expect much from this game. I knew it was old and thought it would be a few days trip. Ha. Haha! 
I ended up running in cities, collecting tinned food and moving heavy garbage containers. I had to hunt zombified animals in swamps and lure unique trophies into specific areas. 
Days turned into nights, when more dangerous species attacked my so recklessly built camp, which led into another adventure (read - vacuuming all visible resources!) and extremely careful preparation for further defences. 

[b]I survived![/b]
There were so many NPCs, sending my to find rare samples and their friends. Seemingly easy missions quickly turned into skills test (I played solo). I found out that multiple zombies could run and my melee attacks often were a bit slow. So I obtained some guns. The shooting noise, however, attracted more infected =/ And then there were quick zombified dogs, acid pelicans, bloody crocodiles! Nasty beings.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3414544819

[b]How to Survive 2 got me 80hrs+ and I mostly enjoyed it. 
Few stupid mechanics annoyed the hell out of me e.g. inability to rotate camera - very often enemies are hidden by a wall or an object. Or my character would do a spinning melee attack instead of a straight hit and miss a zombie. Plus, when running, your character will do a parcour over a chair or car, instead of just "rubbing and running along it".

But generally, lots of positive vibes. Various quests, complex crafting for melee/range weapons AND enhancing medicaments. Moreover, there's a cooking system with more buffs and extra side-effects. 
If you decide to try this game, it's very likely that you'll be grasped by it for many days.[/b] | é–‹å§‹ï¼“ï¼åˆ†å¾Œ

Take it for what it is. A low budget game made by a small team. It's fun for a couple of hours, despite of plenty of quirks. I felt plenty of times that "I wish I have known this before I took this decision" and by "this" I mean a pretty important mechanic that you build your character around. One such example is that you can't go on quests without your main character, hence he can't stay behind and heal. 

Also ludonarrative dissonance (you know, when the gameplay is contradicting the narrative, just as no way of resurrecting a character that dies during a cutscene in FFVII in spite of pheonix down) is very frequent. Among other things, in this game I had to waste a very valuable medkit on a fully healed character because of narrative reasons. | An RPG that is fun enough to be worth your money if you get it on a sale. It has some UI that's unclear and the missions are not also sometimes unclear but fun enough that I enjoyed it nonetheless.

I believe in enjoying a game so here's some quick tips of how to get around better if you decide to get this game (small spoilers on game-play and missions):

First, the missions are all done via inviting the person to join your party and then going to the mission area normally. For example: 
 - Jamal's mission to take him hunting in the woods is done by inviting him to your party and then going into the woods where you will hunt deer via small event popups. NOT putting him and the player on the job for hunting.

Second, for Lydia's mission, note that you must take her to a SPECIFIC diner (which I believe resides at 10/20 on the Highway (Day) map. NOT the small diner events you see in between. (Hence why I said there is some missions which are unclear)

Third, this is just a tip for enjoying the early game, Melee is very important to level to 3 ASAP as breakthrough is one of the few skills that reduce enemy armor, and Melee also don't cost ammo.

Fourth, healing is doable in combat when you get to Medic level 3, and YOU CANNOT HEAL YOURSELF, so plan to have at least two people with medic 3 if you need to heal.

Fifth, healing requires "medical supplies", engineering traps require "engineering supplies", and guns require "ammo", melee is the only thing that is always free. Plan your supplies accordingly.

Overall a hearty recommend, I enjoyed the game, thank you for letting us date certain characters as well, really liked that. I wish there was a way to avoid a specific event as it seems less reasonable that the event pops up even when certain criteria are not fulfilled. Would love to have this event be more dynamic, like it triggers if you fail to have enough resources or make a specific choice instead of this person will always betray you, just let them die.

Dead State (A game I also really like) also had this issue. There were certain characters you were better off not finding as they are guaranteed to lead to difficult events, and since this was unavoidable, the best thing to do is to never deal with those characters, which I felt decreases the immersion in the story in that game as well.

Game Name: Brain Guzzler: The End Is Nigh
Reviews:
Awful game, I was checking some random games in my library and spotted this one: snake with zombies, stupid mechanics and slow animations | Tags: Casual - Lemmings & Snake
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Tabletported quality. Game fails to properly acknowledge inputs making it unplayable.

Review: I was hoping for a Pop-Cap grade game where I could play snake eating humans and going around a level for a bit of casual fun but there was no polish whatsoever, it was tablet port no options menu no controller support, and the inputs were broken where if I pushed directional arrows too fast it would jam the game sometimes up to 7 whole seconds sending my snake into a wall and giving me a game over. For a twitch reflexes based game this is unnacceptable incompetence | It's snake but with zombies, if you like Snake you'll like this. | It's an alright game, but the achievments and in game missions are broken and there is no support available. It's a decent time waster game, but you can get better ones that you can actually complete | It's not bad. It's not outstanding, but it's not bad. The visuals are of fine commercial quality and the controls are acceptable as long as you don't go crazy with them. With some tinkering this could be a winner.

I enjoyed the game and will be looking forward to a sequel to the game. I loved it so much I beat the game to quickly lol. I hope the next one will take the same game make more maps and add new furnishings. I highly recommend the game to anyone looking for something chill and fun to play. | The game used to have its charm until an update in 2024 that introduced employee retirement: after a certain while the employee you've leveled and trained are just simply gone. | It's not very good but it kills the time and makes you click. | Fun little game with a lot of charm | 66666666666666666

Lunch Truck Tycoon takes place on a dystopian, late-capitalist island known as Lunch Island; a horrible place where the same 20 second song is played over loudspeakers on loop at all locations. The days pass by in a rushed blur, yet it is always lunch time on Lunch Island. Strictly segregated by socioeconomic class, the island population is comprised of hunderds of silent and exhausted clones stemming from the same 5 or 6 white people and one brown man in a gray suit, creating an uncomfortable and unsettling atmosphere as you see the same person walk past your truck dozens of times per day. Scared of clowns? Get used to it, 20% of the island's economy seems to be from the clowning industry. The insane dictator they call "Mayor" will randomly threaten to ban products from lunch island for no reason, such as soda, though he seems to have a short attention span and never follows through on his threats, whether you successfully rally the island in protest by selling 10 soda's in 3 days or not.

You COULD pay less than a dollar for Lunch Truck Tycoon, further funding Mayor's regime of white supremacy and capitalist tyranny, or you could play something with just as much, if not more, depth for free on any flash game site. | I've been an avid video-gamer for more than thirty-years, both on PC and console, and I'm a very harsh critic. 

I don't generally waste my time writing reviews for games that are mediocre or just "OK". My reviews will either be very positive or very negative. 

However, in the case of Lunch Truck Tycoon things are a little different. Although I anticipated I would need more time to write a fair review, I only required 30 minutes of gameplay, as shown on my record.

The game is only $0.99 USD. Sometimes we get what we pay for, but in this case, Lunch Truck Tycoon offers just a little more than $0.99 of entertainment. 

I've would've gladly paid $20.00 for this game if there had been more strategy and customization options.

I hope that the developer has plans to expand on this game. I would definitely like to see some improvements via purchasable "add-on's" that increase the need for more strategy, and add more customization. Lunch Truck Tycoon should've been an "Early Access" game.

Will we see a Lunch Truck Tycoon 2 in the future? I hope so!

The development of "Food Truck" themed games has been neglected and is, in my opinion, an untapped oil well that would seriously appeal to the people who enjoy playing "simulation, management, strategy" games.

The game's artwork/graphics are of moderate quality. The animation and gameplay are smooth and moderately clean.

In closing, if you can afford $0.99 USD, buy the game and support an indie developer! In return, you'll receive a little more entertainment than what you paid for, and you can't have a legitimate complaint about that. | Hallo Freunde,
ich bin wirklich ein irrer Tycoon-Liebhaber, denke ich zumindest.
Nichtsahnend guck ich da mal wieder in den Steam-Shop und was entdecken meine kleinen Ã„uglein da?
Lunch Truck Tycoon!!!

Absolut euphorisiert direkt auf den Kaufbutton gedrÃ¼ckt und bezahlt.
99 Cent, die hatte ich gerade noch so Ã¼brig, nachdem heute mein halbes Gespartes fÃ¼r Cola Zero und Tomaten draufging.

NatÃ¼rlich direkt installiert, der Umfang des Spiels wurde mir - bei glaube ich 30 MB - direkt vor Augen gefÃ¼hrt.
Aber gut, fÃ¼r nen Euro sollte man auch nicht allzu kritisch sein.

Mittlerweile habe ich das Spiel fast 30 Minuten gespielt und denke mir nun schon alles gesehen zu haben.
Also umfangreich ist es nun tatsÃ¤chlich nicht so ganz und irgendwie kann man auch nicht viel mehr machen, als den Play-Button drÃ¼cken. Denn das Ganze lÃ¤uft in sogenannten Turns ab, man hat ein paar Orte zur Auswahl wie City, UniversitÃ¤t etc. und die einzige Entscheidung, die man da erstmal trifft, ist: Wo will ich mit meinem kleinen Verkaufsvan stehen.

Es gibt noch sogenannte Events, die aber spÃ¤testens beim zweiten Mal schon irre langweilig sind und ansonsten kommt wieder der Play-Button ins Spiel.
Damit einem die Entscheidung, wo man denn nun mit seinem lausigen Auto rumstehen mÃ¶chte, auch noch abgenommen wird, kommt auf so eine Art virtuelles Handy immer mal wieder eine Meldung, wo gerade besonders viele Leute unterweg s sind.

- fehlende Spieltiefe

>> Positiv
- Preis
- wÃ¤hrend der "Turn" ablÃ¤uft plant man schon einmal seinen nÃ¤chsten Tag im Real Life oder philosophiert Ã¼ber das Leben | For 99 cents, this is a great casual game to kill some time with. If you're into tycoon / management games, this one is a pretty decent bang for your buck. It's not anything spectacular, but I've played worse.

Pros:
-Easy to learn
-Difficulty follows your level perfectly
-Graphics are good for an indie game that costs 99 cents

Cons:
-That damn song! It's one song that repeats on a loop over and over and over and over...
-Some items you can buy don't seem to have much of an effect (such as the banner) | This is one of those Tycoon games where you lose interest very quick. In some related tycoon games, you're purchasing ingredients and are trying to get it right so that you can sell better stuff and make more money. For this one, all you are doing is just restocking and selling it; so there is no creativity involved. There are events where you can try to be creative, but even then it isn't fun and it's all guesses. Also, the upgrades are hard to obtain. Not all the upgrades are available, you need to level up in order to unlock them. The food trucks upgrades are all available, but they are very expensive. In this game, it takes forever to get enough money to get a better truck. Getting a better truck doesn't even do anything; all it does is make more room to put food in your truck. The days are short, so you don't make a lot of money. I literally had to way months until I had enough money to upgrade once. There are events so that you can get extra money and it is a huge help, but you are still a bit away from coming close to buying a new truck. I only play about 2 hrs. worth of the game and I think I'm already done. This should have been an online flash game.

Well... I had high expectations for this game and to be fair - thinking in retrospect now - I quite don't know what I was expecting... I guess I've already played so many CyoA games and I never encountered a game so boring. I mean, the gameplay is kinda fun, I liked the mechanics of managing the money and inventory and the little develop your character gets depending on certain iterations, but I felt really anxious with how fast the clock goes and the routes having to be discovered by pure chance... I mean, for instance, I was really wanting to go through Copenhagen, Warsaw, etc, but the routes were hidden and I had to discover them by talking and choosing the right answers rather than just talking and exploring. That was a bad choice - at least for me - because it forced me to spend +4 hours in a location I really didn't want to explore more and sometimes all this time and exploration wasn't even rewarded properly - at least not the way I wanted, lets say - because, first of all, it was supposed to be just a quick stop to bank and market and than procceed, much because the clock running fast, as I previously mentioned, and the game forced me to spend more time and I didn't get in reward what I wanted or expected. So, yeah, that's what put me off and I guess people should know about this before buying the game. | A casual fun game to pass the time.
Many events, nice music to just relax too on your journeys.
Overall a fun game. | This game is super addicting. I have no idea how many possible routes there are, but all the ones I've tried have offered new adventures. It's very in depth. The difficulty in this game is just unreasonable. After finishing the game I do not feel any kind of accomplishment at all. I am just glad I finished this and now I am free to do something else.

A good picross puzzle game with 150 levels of varying difficulties. One thing I wish the game would have is multicolored puzzles as when it shows you the painting you "painted" in the end it is colored, but the puzzle it is just black. | she queened out :( its a fun puzzle game that is not plot heavy whatsoever so it was always a good game to have off to the side while i was doing something else. sometimes you have to lock in on the puzzle and it can take a while but you'll get there. this game also made me feel smart :3 | Great picross/nonogram style game! Only complaint is that there's no dark mode unless I missed it somewhere.

Genres: Action, Free To Play, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
Reviews: No Reviews

Cute art style, funny presentation, fun gameplay. Just a nice simple game. | A fun game that is easy to learn yet can be quite difficult at times. Once you start playing it continues to captivate you with its thematic artwork and excellent humour. A must try for all deckbuilding fans! | A fun game held back by some limitations in gameplay, some dungeons you just don't draw the map tiles needed to accomplish the goal in a reasonable amount of time. In others you get some powerful items offered and you just run away with the game.
There is some interesting gameplay in the simple style and very simple UI helps this. I didn't have any problems learning how to play the game. (initially I did when I had never played a card game before, and came back some years later to give it another shot and found it comically easy after playing several games now)

You'll lose a few adventurers just down to bad luck, sometimes you'll just get wrecked by being forced to fight an enemy  above their level. And sometimes you (or at least I) make mistakes, it happens but those mistakes can cost your adventurers their lives, something the game makes very clear to the player and it's not even meant to be a big deal, more adventurers will sign up very quickly.

So the interesting thing about this game is the maps are basically randomly generated from a set of tiles/enemies and loot. You build the dungeon, ideally towards a specific goal (kill the boss, collect X gold things and so on), unfortunately it's not quite as fun as it sounds. You'll sometimes get some very strong enemies you have to place, other times you'll get swamped with lots of low level opponents on the map and the dungeon will feel like a chore.
There's a little bit too much rng in what map cards are offered, and no way to edit or adjust the drawing of cards for that mechanic.

The actual combat is fairly quick and once you get to grips with the game. I'll say the first level or two of your adventurers seems to be when they're most vulnerable which is problematic because this is when the players are first using them, so most folk will never find out the stronger versions of your little gang of adventurers. (the traits can be powerful)
The biggest issue for me is that hp is just a bit too important, just a single point is enough to swing the outcome of some fights. 

You get to customise them but it's very basic, some hairstyle changes, rename them and a choice of 1 male or female voice. I started to get glazed eyes after customising my 8th or 9th adventurers, at some point the random visuals don't really matter, all that really matters at least to me was being able to complete the dungeons without losing the adventurers.

The level ups for the adventurers were a little limited, I think they mostly got +1 hp and after completing a dungeon they got a trait. I would have liked a bit of a skill tree to open up, rather than yet more rng.
The only real choice the player has in character customisation is what item they get to pick when they get the option in each dungeon.

The game is okay overall, it functions well (as it should, it's pretty simple in presentation). But eventually I saw through most of the mechanics over time and became a bit disappointed in how it wasn't simple enough to just let me have a fun time (adventurers die pretty easily), or complex enough for me to feel in control (lacking higher levels of customisation in various areas). 
Yet the game is fairly hard, particularly when you're first fighting a type of enemy for the first time in various types of dungeons. Once you get how to beat them it's no big deal, but until that point it's not a fun time.
It is however quick, each run is easily 30 minutes to complete or less so it's hard to feel to upset about it.

Honestly if I could offer on a sliding scale of review somewhere in the neutral region between positive and negative I would. (when I was having fun it was close to 8/10 experience, when I wasn't it was more like 3/10.  I don't know how to boil that down into one score)
You might enjoy what's on offer if you're really curious but for the most part new games do most of what this one does better and in more advanced and/or intuitive ways. 

Ever since slay the spire came out it's hard to argue anyone buy this game over something like that. Or even darkest dungeon. Or a whole host of other card games/rpgs if you want that kind of experience.

I respect this game for trying to tie together card games and dungeon delving but it just wasn't quite there for me. Not strong enough card mechanics to engage me on an intellectual level and not strong enough story/setting to get me immersed in the world/adventurers. Too hard to let me take it lightly and too comedic for me to take it seriously.

Anyways I'd still like to thank the devs for giving it a shot and working on the game for a good while after it came out. So many other devs just abandon projects if they're not immediate successes. | Oddly fun cheeky little game.  

Did you like playing Munchkin with friends, but you got old and got responsibilities?  Never hang out and play games?  This game is like playing Munchkin by yourself.  At least you have memories of having friends, right?

Seriously, though.  Feels like playing the solitaire version of Munchkin.

Love love love this game ! Originally had this game on a old Win 95 comptuer without sound ! This was so good to replay with sound !  Loved this game so much. I don't know why but i was hoping for a little bit more in a remaster. 

I can remember getting stuck for a long time over one simple action and be like "holy fuck, that's what i had to do ?!?!?!?!? . 

Bought this game and beat it in a 2 hour session, just love love love this game ! 

Impossible to lose at this game unless you are not crafty and able to read the storyline well !!! | It's not hard to see why this game is still considered a classic, even for those who aren't superfans of the point and click adventure genre. I played Maniac Mansion on NES years ago and loved it, and while this game is a bit of a departure from it (you don't build a party at the beginning, the three characters don't interact in the same environments), it brings a lot of fun new elements to the table, like the amazing voicework (apart from Laverne, who feels almost comatose by comparison).

The graphics (I played the "retro version", which I'd recommend) are fun and colorful and cartoony, and remind me distinctly of Earthwork Jim. One of my few complaints about the game is the sound design; it's full to bursting with all manner of rehashed Saturday morning cartoon sound effects, which work fine, but the background music is drab and uninteresting. I only bring it up because Maniac Mansion had some of the best music of any game of any generation.

The game does have some intensely moon brain puzzle logic, but in my experience if you're playing a tongue-in-cheek cartoony point and click game, that's part of the package. One of the achievements, which you get after a particularly implausible puzzle, is actually called "Oh yeah, I'm playing a cartoon".

This game isn't for everyone, just as this genre isn't for everyone. But if it's For You, you'll know it. | Geniales Remaster eines der besten Adventures. Schade dass nicht alle Remasters von alten StÃ¼cken so gelungen sind. Viele verhauen die Steuerung total, weil sie der Meinung sind, das Rasd neu erfinden zu mÃ¼ssen.
Absolute Empfehlung! | A classic from the good old days of adventure gaming. Beautiful remaster. | It is what it says. A remaster of the classic DotT. I have not seen anything removed or changed in any bad way. It is the same game - but with better graphics. Also there is a possibility of having some of the creaters comment as you play along. That is a huge feature in itself.

Perhaps it appeals less to people not familiar with DotT. But if so it is a more modern way to play the game.

It is a very well meant and well made remaster of a fantastic game.

NÃƒO JOGUE ESSE POÃ‡O DE CHORUME tem varios jogos na Steam com belos grÃ¡fico e bons enigmas e nÃ£o te penalizam por jogar bem. | I love hidden object games, and have played enough of them to know what a good one is like. While this game has some potential, there is a lot of room for improvement.

Pros: Story line is pretty decent. 

Cons: Each time you explore an area, you use energy, and a large amount of it. You either have to wait several hours for it to replenish or spend money to buy more. The amount of time you are given to explore an area is only 1 minute. This is not enough time to find hidden objects, especially if the graphics aren't that great. If you are zoomed out of a picture, they graphics are nice, but when you zoom in to locate a hard to find object, the graphics become pixelated and somewhat distorted. Also, when you find a chest, you only have a very limited amount of time to solve a puzzle to open it. 

Overall: Game play time is limited and you almost feel rushed to complete puzzles and hidden object areas. | Ich habe ne Quest in dem Spiel bekommen, fÃ¼r die ich das Spiel bewerten soll. Da ich noch nicht allzu viel von dem Spiel gesehen habe, weiÃŸ ich nicht, ob Daumen hoch oder runter.

100% | Many good things are well presented in this game, but the bad things are also obvious. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is "a puzzle game" with a horror theme; not a horror game with puzzles as a side dish. So, if you are a brain-dead person (like me), you are surely not going to make it through this game without a guide as the game gives you very little direction.

The atmosphere is terrific. The sound and character designs are well done. I really like all the elements of this game. However, bad things still exist. First of all, in this game, when the sanity drops, the screen becomes blurry, causing motion sickness and destroying your eyesight; this is very bad, even an FPS gamer like me can barely tolerate it. Secondly, dying makes the game easier; this is a very bad concept for me. Besides these, it is actually a good game. | Playing Amnesia: The Dark Descent in 2025 was an eye-opening experience. Despite its age, it stands tall among modern horror games. The gameplay feels polished, with physics-based interactions that remain impressive. While Iâ€™m not the biggest fan of puzzles, the game strikes a great balance. Theyâ€™re neither too easy nor too hard, and theyâ€™re tied to the narrative in ways that make solving them rewarding.

The story is the heart of the game, delivered in a way thatâ€™s mysterious and compelling. It kept me curious throughout, as every note and memory revealed critical details. Paying close attention to the story isnâ€™t just enriching, itâ€™s essential. The narrative is layered with meaning, and small decisions can impact the outcome significantly.

While the game isnâ€™t overwhelmingly scary, perhaps due to my higher scare tolerance, the tension is palpable. The NPCs are faster than you, so running is often your only option. This mechanic, coupled with the eerie atmosphere, keeps you on edge. One standout feature is the immediate feedback when solving puzzles, which subtly confirms youâ€™re on the right track without breaking immersion.

Itâ€™s funny to think I discovered this classic through PewDiePie years ago. The rich story, creative gameplay, and immersive design make it a must-play, even today. Modern horror games could learn a lot from Amnesiaâ€™s creativity and depth.

Rating: 9/10. Playing it in 2025 was absolutely worth the time. | ĞĞµ Ñ€ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ ğŸ‘

The Deed is a clever, short murder mystery game with a unique twist. The story is engaging, and the decision-making aspect is really fun, as you try to get away with murder in a variety of ways. Game Name: The Order of the Thorne - The King's Challenge
Reviews: This is a very indie and short point-and-click game with a fairy tale story. You are playing a bard who tries to find the king's wife in a fairy kingdom. Pixel art graphics and childish story didn't appeal to me. I also found the game's map is vast and very confusing; you will spend some time wandering around aimlessly, and the lack of a map with shortcuts causes too much backtracking. Voice actors are also just mediocre or bad. $9.99 USD price for this game must be joke! overall I found this game childish, primitive and boring. | my eyes!

Game Name: The Emerald Maiden: Symphony of Dreams
Reviews: One of the better stories in the HOG series I have played from Artifex Mundi. Probably because of another developer, Gogii Games, the story is very interesting and keeps you going. A lot of new or different puzzles, and I played like 10 of these kind of games. I bought it on sale, but it is worth the money. | Definitely not the best HOG game out there. The concept and story had so much potential but was poorly executed, the narration wasn't interesting, the tasks didn't always make sense, sometimes it was difficult to figure out what step logically came next, it seemed like some dialogue/clues were missing when you clicked something that required an action, there was a lot of backtracking (thank goodness for the map and quick travel!), the bonus chapter was absolute nonsense, I saw some basic spelling errors, some of the mini games were horrendous, and while some of the hidden object scenes were unique and good, others were frustrating. This all detracted from how much fun the game was. If you can tolerate and persevere with the trickier hidden object scenes and mini games, then it's not bad to get 100% achievements (use a guide for the collectables as you won't want to play it again!), but it's still a relatively short HOG (3 hours). There are much better alternative HOGs out there that I recommend far more than this one. | gizli nesne bulmaca oyunu fena deÄŸil gideri var konusu gÃ¼zel
Great and addictive game with nice mechanics and fine graphics

Game Name: Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit
Reviews:
Played this game on and off since its release, just beat it, and let me say, its not worth it. very obnoxious floaty controls, the whole warioware kill gimmick facilitates a bunch of shitty bullet sponges. There are ton of weapons but very few enemies worth using them on. Stylish i guess, but man why did i need to finish this game? | Un gran juego de mi adolescencia. En general es muy divertido. Controlar al personaje en la rueda se siente bien. Aunque cuando hay que hacer plataformeo se siente medio tosco. A la hora de usar al personaje caminando es incluso mÃ¡s tosco. Pero el plataformeo es mÃ­nimo asÃ­ que no le doy importancia.
Usar las armas tambiÃ©n es muy divertido, pero el juego tiene un problema de balanceo muy grande. Esto se debe a la tercera mejora de cualquiera de los dos tipos de armas (particularmente las de misiles combinada con la escopeta). Te vuelves demasiado roto al punto de que el jefe final acaba siendo extremadamente fÃ¡cil. Es por esa razÃ³n que el juego agrega muchÃ­simos insta-kills por todos lados. Esta es la manera del juego de agregar dificultad. No sÃ©, se siente medio feo.
Al matar a un monstruo, juegas un pequeÃ±o minijuego. Y estos son pintorescos. Son un detalle mÃ¡s para agregarle mÃ¡s carisma al juego. Sin embargo, creo que hay muy pocos. Te terminas cansando de ver los mismos minijuegos una y otra vez. A veces tienen leves variaciones en los grÃ¡ficos pero nada muy wow.
Los visuales son...algo baratos. El artstyle en general se ve bien, pero las animaciones no tanto. Se nota mÃ¡s que nada en los minijuegos al matar a un monstruo. Algunas cosas apenas estÃ¡n animadas y se sienten como si agarraras una imagen en Paint y la mueves con el mouse.
Hay muy poco que hacer en el post-game. Solo hacer las misiones secundarias, revelar todo el mapa y desbloquear los sombreritos restantes con la isla. DesearÃ­a que hubiera mÃ¡s ya que siento que los juegos de este estilo de exploraciÃ³n deberÃ­an tener otra cosa. No sÃ©, historias secundarias, monstruos secretos, new game plus, algo.
Divertido juego en general. Le vendrÃ­a bien un remake o mejor aÃºn una secuela que mejore en todos los aspectos que mencionÃ©. | literal meu jogo de infÃ¢ncia, e mesmo depois de tanto tempo ainda continua bom
ainda mais por conta da historia engraÃ§ada e das finalizaÃ§Ãµes maneiras | Really funny game.

The controls in this game have not aged super well, but with a little persistence there is still some fun to be found here. It also sucks that it is no longer available on Steam. The main reason that i wanted to post this review was to direct those that want the experience of this game, but with updated controls towards Bomb Rush Cyberfunk. I grew up with Jet Set Radio and Jet Set Radio Future and felt like Bomb Rush surpassed my nostalgia for these games. | One of the greatest games of all time. Very unique. Great music, visuals, and characters. | Good game even 25 years later. It certainly has issues like aged platforming, finicky camera, character movement could be tighter, and some missions being a bit frustrating due to the aforementioned issues along with machine-gun enemies but it's short so it doesn't stick out too much. It's got a good artstyle, simple story,  amazing soundtrack, and interesting level design. I do wish the map would let you choose the different 'sections' but given how old the game is, learning the map and the transition points make sense. If SEGA releases the sequel that's in development, I'll definitely be checking it out. | Wonderful game, not so wonderfully translated gameplay controls. 7/10 if you include the buggy gameplay, otherwise no complaints, I absolutely love this game! | I hope you had a chance to buy this gem. It's hours of fun. I hope the classic Sega titles return at some point with modernized controls and visuals and of course Steam Achievements.

Genres: Casual, Indie, Simulation, Strategy, Free To Play, Early Access
Reviews:
This is the sequel to AdVenture Capitalist, but with a communist twist and completely different interface. The game is a clickcer resource collection game with a nice retro 1950s era look to it. All tho the game is in early access it still plays well and has balanced resources. There are in game purchases to move along quicker but they are not compulsary and you can still advance without them. The dev's seem to take note of the feedback they are given and do regular updates.

Overall an enjoyable game for the clicker genre. | O irmÃ£o russo mais novo do AdVenture Capitalist que nÃ£o deu muito certo!!
Esse jogo tem os mesmo sistemas do AdVenture Capitalist, sÃ³ com uma dificuldade maior que meio que te obrigado a por dinheiro no jogo pra poder evoluir mais rapido seus fundos, pois se nÃ£o, fica igual uma lesma...
Outro ponto negativo Ã© por nÃ£o ter conquistas, que tira a motivaÃ§Ã£o de jogar o jogo...
Mas a Ãºltima gota pra mim foi quando ontem resetaram minha conta do jogo e perdi todo o processo.....................
EntÃ£o adeus AdVenture Communist :v | As of 1/24/17, this game has become MUCH more playable. Comrades are still a part of the game, but they don't accumulate NEARLY as slow as before. There have been numerous, helpful research trial and experiment improvements added, which aid progression even further. The only downside I can think of is that scientists may be a little too easy to stockpile. You only need to 5 to activate the Comrade x7777 trial, which is one of the main reasons why progression has improved. I would either slim down a few achievement scientist awards, or make the x7777 trial a bit more costly. Aside from that, it's gotten a lot better.

This game was virtually unplayable, at a point, for nearly 2 months, but now, it's fallen back on my radar. It's nearly as fun progressing here as it is in AdCap. I'm curious to see what they'll do next. | Adventure Communist, it sounds weird, it might be a little weird, but it's good.

I came here by searching for idle/incremental games to play in my browser, when I heard of this game on steam. I went to the steam page, and I was very suprised about how so polished it is. I've discovered no bugs/expolits, and it makes you feel like you are some kind of god of potatoes, land, ore, weapons, and medicine, as only for playing half an hour, you'll have numbers like 2.87E+008, sounds crazy right? this is why I like the game so much, because it gives you a feeling of acoompilshment for barely doing anything at all! it's glorious! plus, it has funny cartoon pictures of a man building his communist state.

ĞœĞ¸Ğ½ÑƒÑ - ĞĞ§Ğ•ĞĞ¬ ÑĞ»Ğ¾Ğ¶Ğ½Ğ¾ Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ½Ğ°Ñ‡Ğ°Ğ»Ñƒ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ğ¾Ğ±Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒÑÑ.

ĞĞ• Ğ¼ÑĞ¹Ğ½ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¸Ğ¼, Ğ°Ñ€Ñ‚Ñ…Ğ°ÑƒÑ Ğ¾Ñ‚ ĞºĞ»Ğ¸ĞºĞµÑ€Ğ¾Ñ„Ñ„ ! | When it comes to Idling games Idling to Rule the Gods stands in a class of its own. It is well made and has a good story to tie it together. The developer is very engaged and from my personal experiences with him I have to say no other developer has impressed me like he has on a personal level. As a developer the mechanics of this game are solid and have a good amount of depth. Even after a year of on again and off again I can find this game to be enjoyable and pleasently engaging. 

The only Con I can credit to Idling to rule the gods are the grammatical errors and misspelled words. In one chapter it is almost incomprehensible. However, that does not detract from the overall game as a brilliant game in the idling genre. | This is absolutely the best Idle game I have yet encountered.   Seriously.   No, it isn't graphically interesting, but the balance and pacing is -perfect-, the level of complexity keeps things interesting and different, and it has a Story.   Quite a well written one too.   If you are a fan of idle games and number management, this is a great little game to check out.   It's free and fun, and definitely not pay to win(you can pay in a little for boosts to support the devs, but it never feels required). | Tiene una gran idea base, pero la interfaz y la claridad del juego son algo complejas, abrumadoras y llegan a ser aburridoras. Creo que deberÃ­a desarrollarse mejor la interfaz para atrapar al usuario y que entienda mejor el desarrollo del juego, la historia y las opciones que tiene.

Nota 10/8.5 | Welcome to a top down apocalyptic cartoonish survival game from german developer vidiludi who can be found here http://www.vidiludi.com/

Most of the negative reviews on Steam can be summed up into three major spits...

1) A mediocre survival game based on the fact that there is currently limited longevity for many people because there are very few achievements, it has an easy levelling up system, and a low amount of rare and super rare resources. Granted its not early access, but the single developer/team have by no means finished with it adding more and more content in fairly frequent allotments throughout each year. Currently they are working on money quests among other assortment of goodies. So why would you give a game a negative review based on the fact that it's current state is mediocre when there is beyond a shadow of a doubt a huge potential of fun for gamers, especially those who like to make video's? It seems the real problem is some gamers lack imagination and how to have fun.

2) The game was once free and now it is not. This is true, the developer made a risky move to try and get more people to look at his game by making the content free for a period of time. He also added hat and skin cases which are obtainable by doing quests in game and through a micro transaction of a dollar be unlocked, or sold on the steam marketplace instead. However he soon realised that making the content free had a two edged sword about it, on the one hand while it made people more aware of his product, it also allowed in a huge herd of immature trolls that flourished at the expense of others. These trolling kiddies were equally demanding in the discussion board and on the developer himself voicing in a nearly temper tantrum fashion there every whine and lame brained 'I want it now' requests. One therefore can quickly sympathise with the developer why he has wisely moved the game to a very affordable customer bracket who are more likely to appreciate the hard work that the developer has already placed in the game. Also why would you criticise a game for being a dollar when you can clearly just keep collecting hat cases and sell them on the market?

3) I was trolled. My body was driven over several times as a speed bump and my back pack of goodies was stolen and used against my body in a most ungodly fashion, then they blew up my car and placed meat where my dead body was to encourage dogs to come and lick the ground. All I can say to this is toughen up cupcake, its survival dammit. The developer can hardly be blamed for your thighs being too flabby to run from impending danger. Stop eating all those candy bars frequently scattered in all those apocalyptic loot crates.

However, it is true your experience with this game and whether it will be an overall positive or negative one is really more dependent on you and how smart you play. The story of the game is simply survival. You the player are immune from the virus, but the zombies and the gun totting NPC's with gasmasks are not immune and are quickly designed to attack you as they also want to survive. It's not actually easy for another person to kill you. Oh sure they can drive over you, but that's not as easy as it may sound. They can't actually just shoot you either. Each person has a 100% Karma level, only if your Karma level goes down can they start firing at you. Your Karma level will start to drop as soon as you start attacking someone's wall or base, then it's suddenly opening firing range. This means you can defend your base quite easily if your base is being attacked, but they can't shoot you as you haven't been destroying anyone's walls.

Unlike other survival games which demand constant logging in daily, this one has a mechanic which allows a person to leave the game for a long period without the need of again having to start the whole thing from scratch. While it is true that your structures dilapidates with time, items that you have buried in game remain there unless someone uncovers them with a shovel. As long as you keep count of the secret place you have buried your stash, unless discovered by someone by accident it should remain where you buried it, allowing you again to start off with the items you have thus far accumulated. Even with the developers constant upgrades to the game your hidden stash remains safe. It is therefore this mechanic of not having to start the whole thing again from scratch and its relatively stress free nature that makes this apocalyptic game seriously attractive and a fun romp for many.

There are many things to learn, here are a few good hints to get you started.

'Get in the habit of accumulating stuff and burying it. Carrying all your good stuff with you in your back pack is just asking for trouble when you die'.

'If you have steak in your backpack a wandering dog may in fact eat your whole backpack making you lose everything. Fish, drinks are a great alternative'.

'Always make sure you have bandages on you and antibiotics, cloths make bandages quickly.'

'Never bury your good stash within your base. If people break into your base it will be the first place they look. Instead make sure itâ€™s outside a relatively good walking distance from your base to make it harder to locate'.

'If you place a steak underneath a car and wait a while a collection of dogs will come scavenging for the meat they can't reach. Feed each dog individually and you will be rewarded with an army of dogs.'

'Tesla coils can be sniped through windows, make sure your windows are boarded up too'.

I could go on and on about various tips and tricks you could do. Below is a fairly long play through of the game which I intend to add to over the upcoming weeks. We go about trolling other bases and players to show what and what not to do. Whatâ€™s up so far should be enough for you to see if you would enjoy this game. Have fun, stay safe, and be friendly...

A unique and absurd game where you engage in battles using offensive insults. It's got an element of strategy, as you need to find each opponent's weakness and have to carefully choose the most devastating insults from a pool of different random word combinations. Most battles are pretty short, which is a good thing, as the game can get very repetitive if played for longer periods of time. It even has some unlockable characters that are notorious for their catchphrases, like The Postal Dude, Serious Sam or Lo Wang. It's a decent game for a couple of hours, and it's even more enjoyable when played with other friends. | Why does nobody know about this game nowadays?
